In a greenhouse, a small brown bird, a wren, is bumping against the glass. Wrens are seen as mysterious birds, linked to messages and predictions. Is this wren trying to tell me something, or is it just trapped? Both could be true, depending on how you see it. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the direction a wren flew could predict their luck. Today, wrens are still popular in British art and homes. Even if old beliefs have faded, wrens still hold a special place in our hearts. A forest without wrens feels empty and sad.

This connection to birds comes from a long history of folklore. In the past, people depended on nature for survival and developed a way to understand the world through the behavior of animals. This understanding changes over time. For example, in the 1500s, red kites were common in London and were seen as helpful scavengers. But later, they were considered pests and almost disappeared, except in Wales. Now, red kites are protected and have become symbols of conservation in Britain.

Our relationship with birds goes back to early human history. Early humans watched birds closely because they could warn of danger, bad weather, or food sources. Birds also connected people to their dreams. When we think about why birds matter to us, we also think about what it means to be human. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which we admire and envy. Some people might say these feelings are outdated, but they are still part of us. Birds are now seen as indicators of environmental health. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is sad not only because we lose these birds but also because we lose part of our culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing have deep cultural meanings, representing love and magic. Their loss is felt deeply by those who know their significance in literature and folklore.

Folklore is important because it keeps stories and legends alive, connecting us to the past. These stories have more power than scientific terms because they are part of everyday language. They evoke feelings and attitudes that science cannot. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the excitement we feel is hard to explain scientifically. Birds engage us in ways we don't fully understand, and the stories we tell about them help us interpret their messages. The wren in the greenhouse is a mystery, linking the present with a distant past and holding a promise for the future.

Maps

Maps are used to show the relationships between different points and features on the earth's surface. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in time, like "a day's journey by river," which told more about how easy it was to travel through the area than the actual distance. Direction was less important for travelers who mainly wanted to know "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" Because of this, written travel guides were popular for a long time, even more than maps. Some maps, like those showing train routes, still don't focus on true directions. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks, and these signs varied in size to show their importance. The style of maps changed depending on their purpose and location, so understanding early maps requires knowing the specific style used.

The history of map-making, or cartography, is about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and adding more details to maps. Cartography has used other sciences to help with this. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people used the magnetic compass, which allowed for more precise measurements. As people explored more of the world, they tried to map it. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere but is slightly flattened at the poles, which led to more precise mapping of large areas.

Over time, the needs of map users changed. Maps were no longer just for travelers or merchants. Soldiers needed accurate maps for artillery use, which required showing the land's surface features accurately. This led to the invention of contour lines. Archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also needed maps for their work. Today's map makers create maps showing various distributions, like geological layers, climate, and land use. The recognition of maps' value in many sciences has led to a modern revival of cartography.

The development of maps has not been a smooth or continuous process. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid development. Sometimes old ideas stayed alongside new ones. Cartographers often knew what needed to be done but had to wait for better tools to apply their ideas. Since making a map by copying an old one is easy, and because of the investment in printing, map publishers have sometimes resisted new ideas. Therefore, maps should not be taken as perfect evidence of the knowledge and techniques of their time. The many maps we have today are the result of much human effort and thought, making them a valuable record of human history. This is what makes studying historical maps so interesting and educational.

TIM RICE

I was invited into a young man's living room, which was a calm and cultured space compared to the messy rooms around it. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class on a plane. He had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had come across, and he had even bought Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's version of the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as wild; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams weren't as serious to me, although they might have been if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested I try to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein, I was open to it. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very talented. As he played more music from shows he had written at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for praising his music and showing him a seven-inch single of a song I had written, which an unknown pop group had recorded. We promised to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in West End theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I thought I had just met someone with rare talent and determination. I would be foolish not to work with him, as he seemed destined to succeed in musical theatre. Even if we didn't become top musical composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and might need new songs. The next day, back at my desk where I was training to become a lawyer, my brief certainty of a life in show business with Andrew had faded a bit. I would keep looking for groups needing a vocalist and write more simple songs that suited my voice. But it seemed likely I would eventually pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by twenty-five. By then, I might have outgrown pop music, as my father predicted I would by twenty-one. This worried me because if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to see a musical with him and write lyrics like musical lyricists instead of pop stars. Andrew was interesting and talked about good food and Victorian architecture, and he supported Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the musical idea he had been working on for a year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was clear, and he said he had all the contacts. I soon returned to his living room. The idea was about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded orphanages. His story was worthy but didn't excite me. The hero was too perfect, and the project seemed unoriginal, similar to Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. However, Andrew's belief in his music's brilliance was contagious and somewhat justified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent, said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar, there's room for two. We could be the second one. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially on the funny songs. Andrew explained the plot, played the tunes, and often gave me the titles, which his previous lyricist friend had likely thought of. I skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it then, but I had changed careers.

**Language**  
Humans have an amazing ability: we can communicate with each other using language. Language is so important in our lives that it's hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will probably start talking. Even when people are alone, they often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to talk naturally, just like spiders know how to spin webs. Spiders didn't learn web-spinning from a special spider school; it's something they just know how to do.

**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather, created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can shape the look of landscapes. For example, warm and wet climates all year round allow tropical jungles to grow, which are full of many different species. On the other hand, cold and windy areas have fewer living things. Weather patterns, which together form the climate, are caused by large masses of air moving and mixing because the atmosphere is always in motion. Some of this movement happens because the air is on a spinning Earth, and it doesn't move as fast as the planet. The sun is another important cause of air movement.

**Coffee**  
As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks and, more importantly, make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I went through several days of intense training to learn how to use the restaurant's shiny espresso machine. I also learned the key steps to make a perfect cup of rich, frothy cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making good coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might be moved to simpler tasks like cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. He said, 'Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn how to do it well.'

**Art on TV**

Why does television often fail with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be easy for TV to show because cameras can capture the whole artwork and zoom in on details. However, few TV series successfully show both the enjoyment and complexity of viewing art. A good example of this issue is Robert Hughes's series "American Visions," which is about American art. Hughes is a trustworthy critic with a strong personality, and he had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often ignored by British galleries. I expected the series to focus on great artworks, but instead, it was more about how American history and culture are shown in its art and architecture.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a risk-taker. The metals market is less regulated than others. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is a normal part of the industry, and it fits well with a free-market global economy. However, free-trade economists who thought the market would keep metal prices high have found the opposite. More minerals are being extracted, and raw material costs are going down. Considering inflation, most metal prices are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.

Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, stretching from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something unique. **Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK**

At the Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, you can join a course to build your own custom bamboo bike frame. The workshop is located in Hackney Wick, east London. It's a lively place where you can hear the sound of machinery as people work on their bikes. Bamboo is becoming a popular material for bike construction, with companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire using it. However, their bikes can be expensive, costing around $2,995 or £1,868.

James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable. They spent years developing their idea in a shed in Brecon, Wales. They realized they didn't just want to sell bike frames; they wanted to share the experience of making something unique and sustainable. This led to the creation of the Bamboo Bike Club, which is more like a community than a business. James and Ian still have full-time jobs—James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer—but they run monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame for a reasonable price.

During the course, you'll learn how to choose bamboo for strength and how to make strong joints. You'll start by assembling the front triangle of the bike with 40 mm diameter bamboo, then move on to the seat and chain assembly. Metal tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. James and Ian are there to help and supervise, ensuring everything is done correctly.

Building the bike yourself is a big part of the fun, and many participants are engineers. But don't worry if you're not an expert—everyone makes mistakes, and you can always try again with a new piece of bamboo. The bamboo is pre-checked for quality, and you can choose from different styles, like plain, black, or mottled bamboo.

On the second day, you'll focus on building the lugs, or wraps, using hemp bindings and epoxy resin to create strong joints. After adding a waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and other parts. The finished bike is strong and durable, just like metal bikes. Ian has used his bamboo bike for over a year on a 16-mile commute, and James has tested one off-road for three months without any issues.

Bamboo bikes might look a bit rough compared to professional frames, but they have a unique charm. They are great for a relaxed ride rather than racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth, easy-going ride. Bamboo bikes are light and absorb vibrations well, making them comfortable to ride. James says the real joy comes when you take the bike on the road. And the best part? The cost is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**

Dione Reverend was just an editor at Random House in New York when she found a manuscript by an unknown psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She immediately knew it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very successful, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book on communication between men and women is very popular and is part of a growing self-help industry. This industry claims to help people improve their lives, but it also benefits from people's desires to get better. It supports the publishing world in New York. In Britain, the self-help genre is also becoming popular, with many books being published. However, many self-help books are rejected for being too similar to others or too specific. Editors focus on how marketable a book is, asking questions like, "How promotable is the author?" and "Is the idea universal?" A catchy title is very important for success.

**Autobiographies**

When someone writes an autobiography, there is an unspoken agreement with the reader that they are telling the truth. However, this is not always the case. Writers might leave out embarrassing details or things they think are not important. Some writers might even invent stories to better express the truth about themselves. Others might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is fiction. This is not always done with bad intentions.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**

Detective stories became popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries because they reflect the conflicts of that time. These stories are like allegories, where the crime represents human desires like lust or greed. Solving the crime shows how society can return to normal. In Hammett's stories, society is shown as corrupt. The detective and the criminal understand each other and are similar. The detective is both a part of the law and a bit of a criminal. His mission is complicated by his understanding of both sides.

**Science Writing**

Stephen Jay Gould is a well-known science essayist. He believes that to write well about science, you need to understand the scientific community. He says you should never simplify the argument for the reader, even if you simplify the language. If readers feel they are being talked down to, they will lose interest.

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym in the City of London, the air feels very cold. The gym has used a lot of air-conditioning to deal with the very hot summer. Sometimes, it feels as cold as the Arctic inside. This is an example of how people often use too much air-conditioning. Air-conditioning is now a big part of our lives, showing how we can control or change the climate. However, many buildings could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and air, and have thicker walls that keep out heat during the day and release it at night. These simple ideas can work well and reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, people are again interested in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were important for keeping time accurately. But as clocks and watches improved, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are taking them seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are popular because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are calm and romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

I used to think china-painting was only for very skilled people. I once saw older women at an arts and crafts show painting teacups with perfect flowers. They were so precise that it seemed they had been doing it for many years or had a special talent. I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting class. Would beginners also be naturally good at it? But when I visited a class, it was not scary at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers on teacups as quickly as I remembered.

Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent told them that the other people in their package were a school group learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland. 

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe there was a cancellation or the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed. 

When they arrived, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but Keith thought it was just a stopover. It was almost midnight when they got off the coach, and they were too tired to question the situation. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. 

The receptionist told them about the lake and the steamer to Interlaken. Keith calmly explained there was a mistake; they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn't know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip. 

A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, approached them. Dawne explained they were in the wrong hotel. Keith said they followed the wrong group. Mrs. Franks explained that many holidays have similar tickets and labels, and it was easy to follow the wrong group. 

Keith insisted they were not supposed to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks left to check, and the receptionist was gone too. Dawne thought Mrs. Franks seemed kind. Keith tried to remember everything that happened at the airport. An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, talked to them about how well they slept. 

Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They didn't mention the irony of ending up on a holiday with elderly people when they wanted to escape the demands of the elderly. Uncle had insisted on this holiday for them.

**He Was a People Person**

American business leaders are now looking up to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a great example of good management. Eluned Price reports on this trend. In Britain, many people know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a basic idea of his achievements. However, in America, he is only recently becoming well-known. The Wall Street Journal even called him 'an Antarctic explorer whose feats went unnoticed for most of the 20th century,' which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are very enthusiastic about him. Many biographies and stories about his famous voyage on the Endurance are being written and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a movie about Shackleton's life.

Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his actions and learn lessons in leadership and communication from his story. They even use the term 'speaking Shackleton' among themselves. Shackleton, known for being determined and resourceful, is now a model for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has been inspired by Shackleton for years. His company deals with communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises, like when a company's plant explodes or when many employees are laid off.

Shackleton once worked in public relations for a Glasgow steel company, but it might be hard to see how surviving on albatross meat in freezing temperatures relates to handling a financial crisis. MacGregor says, 'Even if a company manages its crises well, it can still cause problems if it communicates poorly.' Shackleton is a model for management because he was a great leader and communicator. He had strong values and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of Shackleton's most important decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This decision showed his credibility for future expeditions because he prioritized the lives of his men.

In 1908, Shackleton's expedition to the South Pole was 97 miles short of their goal. With supplies running low and limited time to return to their ship, Shackleton made the brave decision to turn back. In a crisis, MacGregor says, people want to know someone is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take it. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually crushed. Shackleton told his men, 'We will all reach safety if you continue to do your best and trust me.' From their diaries, it's clear that Shackleton was always in charge.

Shackleton planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions. He was flexible and ready to start over if needed. MacGregor says, 'We've created a set of principles based on Shackleton's story. Clients can relate to it without feeling criticized.' Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. MacGregor adds, 'One of the hardest things to do in difficult times is to wait, especially in America, where people want quick solutions.' For example, if you buy bonds and the interest rates change, you should wait instead of selling at a loss. Also, don't be afraid to change plans if they're not working. If a new product fails, stop selling it.

Shackleton led by example. On the return journey from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if Hurley didn't wear them. Someone else remembered Shackleton doing the same with a biscuit when they were starving in 1905: 'He said he'd leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds couldn't have bought that biscuit.' Caroline Alexander, author of "Endurance," says, 'People are more interested in heroic stories now. Shackleton shows that there is little heroism today. He stands out as a true example of the ideals we miss.'

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that has a lifestyle similar to a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye search for insect larvae inside wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to gnaw into the wood and its long, thin third finger to reach and scoop out the insects.

Although scientists described the aye-aye's feeding habits over a hundred years ago, they have only recently discovered how it finds insects hidden in the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of some aye-ayes named Nosferatu, Poe, Samantha, and her daughter Annabelle. He tested if they found insects by looking for visual signs, like holes on the wood surface. He gave them logs with drilled holes, some leading to mealworms and others to empty spaces. The aye-ayes went directly to the mealworms, showing they didn't rely on visual clues.

Dr. Erickson also tested if the aye-ayes used smell or sound to find the insects. Even when the smell was blocked, and the insects were dead and silent, the aye-ayes still found them. It seemed they could sense the empty spaces in the wood. The aye-aye taps the wood with its middle finger and listens with its large ears. Dr. Erickson thinks they use echo-location, listening for sounds that indicate a hollow space below. They might also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping.

The idea that the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting, but there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also search for insects in wood. The aye-aye is unique because it combines features of a woodpecker, an echo-locating bat, and a squirrel. Its teeth grow continuously like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild gnawing through nut shells and using its long finger to get the nut meat.

Title: 'Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives'

Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we really know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries and family stories often give us only small, incomplete pictures. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they still don't tell the whole story.

Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people, creating a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if wanted. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary ones. The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realized how much of the past was being forgotten. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "People do it for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy it themselves."

The promise of privacy helps people be honest. A 62-year-old man who made and lost a fortune said, "I was surprised at what came out. There were painful things, like my divorce." He did it for his family, hoping they might learn something, but hasn't let his children read it yet. He thinks they should read it after he is gone.

Ms. Renier has noticed that many people repeat patterns from their childhood. "It's amazing how many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "Things their parents said or did affect them for life. They might marry someone their parents would like, or do the opposite to rebel."

Many people still feel disappointed about things that happened long ago. Even in middle age, they try to impress a parent who was never impressed. Some want to say, "I can't stand my mother."

Ms. Renier listens and writes, but she is not nosy. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to pry. People sometimes tell me things and then say, 'I'm not sure if that should go in.' I include it, but they can remove it later. Most people want to be honest."

This is not about showing off. It's about keeping a connection to the past. We are losing touch with history because families don't stay together like they used to. People want a little bit of immortality.

Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story. Modern technology helps her produce everything except the book cover. The final product is high quality and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost stops many people. "I thought it would be more affordable," she says. "But the people I've worked with are often wealthy, like readers of Harpers & Queen, where I advertise. They are the kind of people who might have had their portraits painted for their descendants."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, none of the sculptures here are real; they are all accurate copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with great natural light. Plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery that shows different photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (aged 12 to 16) with our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photographic books, magazines, and a full range of photographic materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a wonderful collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world and from all geological ages. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, belonging to Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), with nearly 10,000 rare and interesting specimens in their original early 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, greatly expanded the collections, creating an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, showing major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
This collection has over 400,000 air photographs, both oblique and vertical, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos throughout Great Britain. The photos are interesting as they show detailed records of the landscape, including natural environments and human activities from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the knowledgeable library staff can help with inquiries. The photos cannot be borrowed, but copies can be purchased, usually taking about a month to make.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world and is a unique tourist attraction. Visitors can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By creating resin copies, known as facsimiles, the center preserves the originals while allowing everyone to enjoy brass rubbing. Brass plates, used as memorials instead of tomb statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining brasses are in Britain, with the widest range at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I have had 35 years of raising young children, and I have loved every moment of it. This morning, I fed the baby, and for me, that's what being a father is all about. I'm very lucky because my children and I share interests like opera, theatre, books, and music. This has created a strong bond between us, especially now that they are mostly grown up, and I am more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in physical punishment. I have slapped my children in anger before, but I don't support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be available. I'm here if they need me, but I let them contact me first. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't been in touch, it creates a burden of guilt. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was young when my children were born, around 25, and I found the responsibilities difficult. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion. This has been very helpful for my work at the agency. I have never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy building my business, so I missed some important events like their first concerts and sports days. I feel sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and come to parties and advertising award ceremonies with us without feeling shy. I think it's an advantage that they see my job as glamorous and interesting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public events where my kids can come with me. This way, they know what I do when I'm not with them, and there's no feeling of me disappearing. I've noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all realizing the importance of involving our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think a lot about being a father. I worked hard to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next door to each other so the kids could come and go as they wanted, but I think they found it confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I'm not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently complained that we were too liberal. I think I should have been more organized. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a nice house, so we thought, "Why keep spending money on new things when we could have a child instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are, but you also become just another parent. It's a great equalizer. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but one look at her and it goes away. A baby's smile is the best way to melt a grown man's heart.

THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER

A. Tamburlaine the Great
Marlowe's long play about a powerful warrior can feel endless, but in Terry Hands' version, it becomes one of the most exciting shows of the year. He has cut a lot from the original text, making it fast and full of action. Antony Sher is amazing in the main role, doing stunts like somersaulting from a balcony and sliding down a rope while speaking. His performance is captivating as he shows a strong desire for power and glory. Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)

B. Women Laughing
This play by the late Michael Wall, first shown in Manchester, is now in London. The first part creates a tense feeling as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second part, the setting changes, and the play becomes a deep look at the effects of illness. Wall was a talented playwright who died too young at 44. Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)

C. Amphibians
Billy Roche, an Irish playwright, brings another play to the English stage. Set in Wexford, it explores the decline of the fishing industry with strong characters, deep emotions, and funny moments. The play can feel a bit unfocused but ends with a powerful climax. Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)

D. Murder by Misadventure
A classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play crime writers who want to kill each other. The story is familiar, but the twists are cleverly done. Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)

E. The Alchemist
Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century con artists. First shown in Stratford, it works well on the Barbican's main stage too. Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce give great performances as the tricksters. Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)

F. The Madras House
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after success in Edinburgh. The production is stylish, the acting excellent, and the play is an overlooked classic. Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)

G. Dreams from a Summer House
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a charming version of the Beauty and the Beast story set in London suburbia. With music by John Pattison, it celebrates romantic love and is a feel-good show. London producers should check it out. Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)

H. The Merry Wives of Windsor
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy almost got a bad review, but it is saved by great comic performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as Ford. Most of the other actors seem uncomfortable. Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)

I. The Voysey Inheritance
Another revival of a Granville Barker play, now touring. It tells the story of a seemingly honest lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son, resulting in a great play. Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)

**Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard**  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her feelings for him and trying to separate her from her friends. Coppard describes Emma's friends well. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes intense. She is trapped in the basement of an old house, and this part is very well written. The book shows details of family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always the protectors they should be. It's an important and believable read.

**Backtrack by Peter Hunt**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, discover that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. They work together to understand what happened, using different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts. The novel is clever and complex, rewarding readers who pay close attention.

**Pigeon Summer by Ann Turnbull**  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit well into her family or the male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves to find work, she takes care of them and wins prizes, despite conflicts with her stressed mother. Set in 1930, this story has a strong message that there are different kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.

**Yaxley's Cat by Robert Westall**  
In this chilling story, Rose, a mature woman, rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage to escape her materialistic life and her smug husband. She moves in with her two children. A fierce cat and strange items in the house reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The locals become hostile, putting their lives at risk. By the end, the violence is controlled, but Rose is upset by her teenage son's ruthless behavior. It's a gripping story.

**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam, who is from the poorer side of the family, is impressed by his cool and sophisticated cousin, Lisa, from the richer side. When Lisa's world falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and both learn the value of family. The story is a bit slow in parts but has gentle humor. The growing closeness between the two teenagers is well portrayed. It appeals to both boys and girls.

**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, bringing his New Zealand setting to life. Robbie, the narrator, takes a job gardening for Stanley, an elderly man. At first, Robbie finds Stanley interesting, but later he is repelled by him. When Robbie discovers what Stanley keeps in his aquarium and his plans, the story takes a thrilling turn while still exploring character and relationships. It's unusual and compelling.

**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has troubled personal relationships and a difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a sympathetic narrative. Mick improves his self-worth through a role in a school play and with the help of a sensitive first-year teacher. It's highly recommended, though it's a tough read, especially at the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a regular airplane. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, similar to a Boeing 707 passenger plane. But inside, it was different. The 13 students from Europe and America were about to have an unforgettable flight. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, except for a few at the back where the nervous students sat. For a year, they competed with other students to join this flight, a challenge by the European Space Agency to propose creative experiments in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a spot on this unique flight, which was like an extraordinary roller-coaster ride.

For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly like a giant bird, going up and down. The goal was to create a weightless state at the top of each curve. At 3,000 meters, the pilot cut the engines, and the plane continued upward by momentum before gravity pulled it down again. In those few silent seconds between going up and falling, everything inside became weightless, and the students felt closer to the moon than Earth.

The takeoff was smooth, but any thoughts of a normal flight disappeared when the pilot made the plane climb at a 45-degree angle for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and we were scattered across the cabin floor. Then the engines stopped, and we instantly felt weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence: the floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us towards the ceiling. We floated aimlessly; directions like left, right, up, or down no longer made sense. Only gravity helps us understand movement.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned suddenly, causing some students to land with a bump. After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves gave ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They used a device to turn it belly-down with radio controls. During another curve, a student accidentally landed on it. Nearby, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joins are affected by no gravity, important for future space stations. A team from Utah State University explored making solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by sunlight. They tried to create these films in microgravity, believing satellites could use solar sails like yachts use wind.

After two hours of swinging between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unstable, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This feeling would last a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I wanted to become an astronaut before, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**

**Jonathon Porritt Talks to Danny Danziger**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.

I had a unique time in my life when I didn't experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer from here, which is winter in New Zealand, so I had nine winters in a row. I enjoyed it because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was nice since my father grew up there. They found a plot about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was suitable for planting trees.

I've always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing various farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees sounded great to me. I was eager to start, and my family became enthusiastic as we progressed. We began planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the entire 70 acres.

In 1968, it was a very rainy winter in New Zealand. It rained almost every day while we were planting, and I don't think I've ever been wetter or colder for such a long time. Every morning, there was a moment of truth: getting ready for another day of planting. We would step out of the Land Rover, warm and dry, into the rain, with our anoraks still damp from the day before, boots soaked, and hands struggling with wet laces.

In the first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which was helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. You carry a planting bag around your neck filled with as many trees as possible. When the bag is full, it's difficult, but it gets easier as it becomes lighter. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. You decide the spacing for the trees, line up three poles across a long distance, and those poles guide your lines. Once aligned, you plant all the way down the line, turn around, and come back.

I enjoy hard physical work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically, finding a rhythm and using the fewest spade strokes needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is common in many farming jobs, where you train your body to perform standard moves, making the process easy: taking the tree out of the bag, digging a hole, planting it, stamping it in, and moving on.

Mentally, it's interesting. Your mind starts to wander, and you think about life. Many of my thoughts about the natural world and our place in it began during those days. I've returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is satisfying because I planted them and feel connected to their success. I worry when I read about storms or droughts in New Zealand, but the trees are now 20 years old and doing well.

In 1984, I took a break from teaching and returned to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, there. There's a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. My connection to that area is still very strong. It's the place where I feel most connected to the earth, a powerful bond.
