Text: 'In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to map compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was mapping 'compass variations' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors couldn't correct their compasses, making it hard to find longitude and navigate the seas. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at the time, set sail for the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. The trip was stopped early due to crew problems, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these travels, Halley published a 'New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans' in 1701. This chart was very useful to sailors for over a century until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it outdated. Dr. Clark, who enjoys sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley during a two-year stay at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist. 'Halley led a remarkable life,' says Dr. Clark. 'He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He wasn't just an astronomer; he also did research in geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and found time for other interests.' During this time, Halley developed a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton on his book Principia Mathematica, the foundation of classical physics. Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking the same measurements Halley did, but with more precise instruments. These measurements need updating because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data collected will help improve the current model of Earth's magnetic field, known as the international geomagnetic reference field. 'It's common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. You need to know true north to measure the direction,' says Dr. Clark. 'On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find that.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements globally. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean and notes that ground-based measurements are useful for comparison. It's easy to forget how important Halley's Atlantic journey was. It was the first scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian appointed as a naval captain to pursue what many saw as an obsession with declination. Does Dr. Clark have the skills to make his voyage successful? Besides spending two years in Antarctica and working in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey, he has already sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with four different crews. Does he share Halley's obsessive nature? 'I'm willing to dedicate eight months of my life to this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to cross the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peacocks, or hens. This display raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: in a world where survival is tough, why do peacocks have such extravagant tails? Darwin believed that animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the strongest and smartest survive. However, the peacock's tail seemed to be a disadvantage, so Darwin suggested another idea called 'sexual selection.' He thought females chose mates based on beauty alone. 

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He believed that if hens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a reason beyond just looks. Wallace thought the tail might signal some hidden quality that helped survival. Today, scientists like Marion Petrie are studying peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers. They want to know if hens really prefer males with the showiest tails and if these males have other advantages.

Observations show that hens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails, which attract more mates. However, it's unclear if these males are better in other ways. Some scientists, like William Hamilton, suggest that showy males might be healthier and free of parasites, but this hasn't been proven in Whipsnade peacocks yet. 

This year, Dr. Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males to see if the former grow faster or are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is practical. 

There's another theory by R.A. Fisher called 'Fisher's Runaway.' It suggests that if females start preferring slightly better tails, over generations, this preference and the trait itself will grow stronger. This could explain the peacock's tail and support Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with the latest technology. Most of these yachts are based on design changes from 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly anchored in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. Some might think I'm a romantic dreamer, but I don't think so. My boat uses the best of old boat designs, but modern technology made it easier to build. However, while technology is important in boat design today, it often separates sailors from the real experiences of being at sea. These are the experiences they wanted to find by sailing. I'm not saying sailors should suffer, but I believe boats should have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. But why sail if everything is done automatically? Sometimes, dealing with sails is part of the adventure. Also, why move the steering from the safe back of the boat to a risky spot in the middle? This change is often made to create more space inside, like a big cabin. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a floating house. 

When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, for a TV race around Britain, the former owner said it had comfort but no luxury. During my time with Hirta, I learned he was right. Hirta had heavy sails, no pumped water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest boat I've ever sailed. However, old boats need a lot of care. After a back injury, I realized I had to let Hirta go. I couldn't find a suitable new boat, so I decided to build one. The Westerman has never let me down. Designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett used computers for the design, but Irens first sketched the boat on a napkin. He then made a model, like in the old days. We reviewed the model and made changes on the computer. The final design was perfect. The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. She looks timeless, sails beautifully, and her interior, made from reclaimed wood, feels peaceful. This is because she was designed as a sailing boat first, without focusing on furniture. This traditional method works well. The Westerman shows that you don't need to follow trends to be happy and that history can teach us valuable lessons. Made from wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. She has all the benefits of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a classic wooden boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was excited to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed a break. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt relaxed right away. On the first day, I rested and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like body conditioning, yoga, and stretching. The instructors are very skilled, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, such as aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The one-hour facial made me feel refreshed. The staff were friendly and professional, creating a lively and enthusiastic atmosphere. Henlow plans to add a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room this year. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds or enjoy a walk in the garden. My mood and appetite improved during my stay, and I left feeling energetic. I look forward to visiting again. This is a great break for busy working women. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

The calm and relaxing atmosphere of this grand home was clear as soon as I entered. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and lots of space, so you can have privacy if you want. Everyone gets a medical check-up on arrival, which includes checking weight and blood pressure. We were called patients, which felt strange since I am healthy. However, they found a shoulder problem during the check-up, and the fitness instructor helped me with it in group and individual sessions. Each person gets a specific diet plan. I lost weight without fasting, but I was hungry and got a headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and exotic fruit with yogurt and hot broth for dinner. If you're not on a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. You get a massage or water therapy every other day, and extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm and doesn't claim to be. It's a charming old manor with cozy log fires and a large lounge. If you're watching your weight, you might want to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and delicious desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a pool to help burn off the extra calories. You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight. There is also a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic, where I got advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside nearby. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a famous restaurant, offers amazing dishes. The dinner menu has many choices, and the meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden offers fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments if you want them, before enjoying a meal at Waldo's. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's the best because it's delicious, but the worst because it's 360 calories, which isn't great if you're trying to lose weight. You've been warned! The second best thing is the wonderful aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep twice during the massage. I returned to my room feeling refreshed and had a great night's sleep. The facilities are modern and well-run, with luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so it's easy to schedule appointments. They offer a variety of treatments, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. Guests include football teams, mothers and daughters, best friends, and singles. I would love to visit here once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans split from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically. We are still more than 98% the same as chimps. This means that what makes us different from animals is a recent development. Our ability to create art and other human traits must come from a small part of our genes. This is why studies show that the differences between humans and animals are often just a matter of degree. For example, both humans and animals use tools: chimpanzees use sticks, and sea otters use rocks. Monkeys have simple languages with different sounds for different predators like leopards and snakes. 

The main difference between us and animals might be art. But if art is a unique human trait, it's strange that our ancestors didn't create it for most of our history. The earliest art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these don't last over time. Clear evidence of human art, like cave paintings and statues, only appears around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.

If we say our art sets us apart, we often claim three things: human art is not useful, it's made for pleasure, and it's learned, not instinctive. Let's look at these claims. First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means human art doesn't help us survive or reproduce, unlike most animal behaviors. For example, birds sing to defend territory or attract mates, which helps pass on their genes. By this measure, human art is different.

The second claim is that human art is motivated by aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, suggesting they sing for reasons other than pleasure. Again, human art seems unique here.

The third claim is that human art is learned. Different human groups have distinct art styles that are learned, not inherited. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds inherit their songs and would sing them even if they never heard them. It's like a French baby raised in Japan singing the French national anthem without being taught.

Human art changes quickly. Geese honked 2,000 years ago as they do today, but human art evolves fast. Even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake paintings by two chimpanzees, Congo and Betsy, for human art. Congo created many paintings in a day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. In 1957, their paintings were shown in London, and many were sold, which some human artists can't claim.

These chimpanzee paintings blur the line between human art and animal activities. Like human art, they weren't made for practical reasons but for the painter's satisfaction. You might argue that human art is different because it's meant to communicate. However, some famous human art was created for the artist's personal satisfaction, not to communicate with others.

Title: A Big Adventure

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that hasn't been fully explored. It's also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to share his story. Today, there are not many big adventures or heroes left. In the past, children's stories often featured brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes focused on distant horizons as they journeyed into the unknown. Nowadays, such people are rare in both fiction and real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore led an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert, one of the last unexplored places on earth. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', and locals call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of the journey while sitting calmly at home. His team included four Britons (one was a medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were actually long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous and put the expedition at risk.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's toughest deserts. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to prove something to himself. 'I always thought I'd spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to find out who Charles Blackmore really was, outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'

Anyone reading about their crossing might wonder why he used the word 'kind'. The team faced many hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst and dehydration, and losing part of their water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at our limits and the camels hadn't had water for seven days, we found some. We didn't face the Taklamakan's famous sandstorms. And we never experienced the freezing desert cold that could have stopped us completely. That's not to say we didn't face challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the camels, which often fell over onto us.'

'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn't allow for one. No aircraft flew over us. Once we were in the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was worried about my physical ability. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" At that moment, I was very scared.'

If it was like that at the start, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've been through so much; you have so much behind you. We were very thin but strong and muscular despite being exhausted. My body was well-toned, and my legs were like pistons. I could walk over anything.'

In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking at a full moon, and thinking of his family. How aware was he of the challenge it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I doubt myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we managed to do it. As a personal achievement, I'm prouder of that expedition than anything else I've done. But in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share -- compared to that, the desert doesn't measure up.'

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I long for the challenge -- for the open spaces -- the purpose of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it hard now to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Susan Harr decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and save time. However, Susan realized that technology might not be as great as it seems. She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which was expensive to fix. This made her question if we really need all these gadgets.

Susan started letting her household gadgets go when they stopped working. She wondered if technology really gives us more time or just makes us buy more gadgets. When her sewing machine started making strange noises, she left it in the backyard and began sewing by hand. She found it freeing not to be tied to a noisy machine and enjoyed taking her time with her sewing projects.

There are some gadgets Susan still values, like the washing machine, but she found joy in losing others. She returned her rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This made her focus on what was worth watching and spend more time on other activities like walking the dog, reading, and talking.

Sewing by hand became a new hobby for Susan. Her old sewing machine became a plant table, and she couldn't afford a new one, so she sewed by hand. She realized that doing things by hand wasn't as bad as she thought. It was relaxing and satisfying to see her work improve. She found that life slowed down to the pace of her hands, and she didn't have to rush from one task to another.

Susan also enjoyed washing dishes by hand, which gave her time to daydream. She started to question if she really needed other gadgets like the freezer, microwave, or lawnmower. She even thought about saving money by not using electric lights.

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. When I visit his workshop in East London, he seems to be in a hurry. He greets me quickly and tells me to start the interview. His workshop is busy, filled with half-made furniture and colorful wood. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a great reputation. He is always busy with orders, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if they want quality furniture like cupboards, tables, or bookcases, Hurst is the person to go to.

Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes simple, well-crafted pieces is rare. Hurst is disappointed by some modern furniture and criticizes mass-produced, low-quality pieces. His quest for perfection and his talent are keys to his success. He is confident in his skills, saying he has a natural ability for making things. Hurst is self-taught and learned by asking the right questions.

Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return for more pieces. He finds it satisfying to furnish a whole house. However, he admits that not all client relationships are smooth. He prefers clients who know what they want. Hurst also praises others when deserved, acknowledging that some are better than him. He criticizes craftsmen who take too long to make one piece and students who try to make fashion statements with their work. For Hurst, furniture should be practical and usable.

Despite his confidence, Hurst is humble about his work. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Text: 'Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This suggests that sleep is very important. However, scientists still do not fully agree on why we need to sleep so much. There are three main theories. The most common theory says that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It suggests that while we sleep, our body repairs any damage from the day and restores our energy. Another theory focuses on the learning benefits of sleep. It suggests that sleep helps us process and understand the information we learn during the day. Without sleep, learning would be difficult. The third theory is about energy. It says that we need sleep to recharge our energy, like recharging a battery, so we have enough energy for the next day.'

Eccentrics are people whose behavior is different from what is considered normal in society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own unique habits, like entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to newspapers about various topics. Eccentricity is about showing our individuality. Inside us, there is a struggle between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains pushing against each other on the same track: one is individualism, and the other is conformity. For most people, the desire to be accepted and loved is stronger than the desire to stand out.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often gather together. They form clubs and hold meetings to share their interests, which others might see as odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, is comforting. We all feel a tension between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. We might say things like, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me," to show our individuality.

At any time, we can choose to be more individualistic and show our personality. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said that when you follow your instincts and don't give up, you might confuse others. But this self-expression is not eccentricity, at least not at first. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, it's not eccentricity. However, if they continue these behaviors until they become a natural part of who they are, then they might be considered eccentric.

The key to being eccentric is being natural. Eccentrics don't try to be different; they just are. They are not concerned with what others think. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses, who are all aware of society and react to it. Eccentrics simply do what they do because of who they are, without worrying about society.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**

Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've met many important figures in the field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small but powerful woman who was central to environmental issues in post-war Europe. She combined her experiences into a strong philosophy. As a young journalist, her work helped me understand the field. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man," despite its old-fashioned title, is her most important book to me. It focuses on the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about, like sustainable development. I've read many books since, but none match its impact.

**B. Linda Bennett**

When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can almost hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their colony. This book explains animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to an organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special. Ennion's paintings, with simple lines and colors, show the behavior of gulls clearly. This is the work of a true field naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**

"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book confirmed my love for the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was facing many challenges, but reading this book made my world brighter. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty all connected, a world worth saving. Some say humans are the worst species because of the harm we've done. But I think of Gerald as a boy, seeing the world as a family, all connected. This is a concept we all need to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**

I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and had learned to identify birds during holidays. They inspired me to start sketching birds to help with identification. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered much more. It included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images made me appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was as valid as a scientific one. Since I was better at art than math or physics, it opened a new path for me.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five top British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here’s what they said:

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. The Book Marketing Council found that more people buy books because of reviews than for any other reason, like ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are usually less upset by bad reviews. They think that any mention, whether good or bad, can help sell books because readers want to decide for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinion of the book since they are often the first to read it.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and the press both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are still often ignored. Publishers need reviews because they help make a book and its author known. A good review by a trusted person can boost sales, especially if there are several reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are crucial for literary publishing. Without them, we would miss an important way to reach readers. We publish books by less-known authors, so we rely on reviews since we don’t advertise much. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as honest opinions. Reviews can help sell books, but they need to work with other things like word-of-mouth, support from bookstores, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
In Britain, the link between publishing and reviews is unclear. In the U.S., a review in the New York Times can greatly affect a book's success. Here, bookshops don’t always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for a writer to become popular. Some poorly reviewed books sell very well, so it’s unpredictable. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer’s knowledge than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want long, positive reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it didn’t sell well because people felt they didn’t need to buy it after reading the reviews. The reviewer’s name used to matter more, but now it’s the surprise choice of reviewer or the quality of the review that can persuade people to buy a book.

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, dating back to ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith keeps this tradition alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. He says, "This way, I can make a special item just for them." Many of his customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want something special that shows the man's job or hobbies. 

Unlike the usual cockerel design, Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick, which he made as a surprise for his wife. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. Graham realized he could make weathervanes in many different shapes and decided to start a business. He used to be a precision engineer for 15 years, but then he and his wife, Liz, switched roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of their children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. "My old job wasn't creative, but this is exciting," he says. "I love designing."

Graham has created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval before cutting the design by hand. He also keeps traditional designs in stock because they are popular too. "People like handmade things," Graham says. "They like having something unique." He doesn't plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a small, rural craft. "I've found my place in the market," he says. "People love the uniqueness, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike."

Weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather for centuries by showing changes in wind direction. Now, more people are moving to the countryside and want unique touches for their homes, which helps crafts like Graham's. He is getting busier, sending flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world, especially in America and Denmark. "The price," he says, "depends on how detailed the design is." His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

Title: Beginner Takes All

Before it was even published, "The Horse Whisperer" was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about what inspired him and his success.

At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and wanted to be a director. His year started badly when a film project called "Life and Limb," which he had been working on for months, suddenly failed. He was worried because he hadn't made any money for two years, and this film was his only hope to avoid problems with his bank manager. A sensible person in Evans' situation might have looked for a job. He could have returned to working in television or started a TV project he had paused. Instead, he made a risky decision. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching his first novel.

Even though he was acting on impulse, the idea for the story had been with him for a while. It started when he met a farrier (a person who shoes horses) on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. Such people were called "horse whisperers." This story captured Evans' imagination. He started researching the topic to write a screenplay, as he was a filmmaker. But after "Life and Limb" failed, he decided to write it as a book.

In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he says now. "I was watching people, but I was mostly alone and felt like my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, worried about feeding my children, and wondering if it was all a mistake."

By the end of August, he was back home and had written the first half of the book. "The bank manager was getting really serious with us, and I needed to know if it was worth continuing. I showed it to a friend who was a literary agent; he read it and said it was 'fine.'" When asked, the agent thought Evans might get $30,000 as an advance for the book. "I had an idea of how much I needed to pay off some of the debt and keep us going, and it was more than that. I had spent seven months on 'The Horse Whisperer,' and there were at least two more months to go. $30,000 was a tough number. I was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book."

In October, along with the first two hundred pages of the novel, this summary was sent to seven UK publishers just before they left for the Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. "I said, 'You what?' And he said, 'It's OK, I just feel something is happening.'"

What happened next became publishing history. Within a week, after intense bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record-breaking advances for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were shocked. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. They also didn't send it to Hollywood, but within that same week, major studios were competing for it. "My agent in the UK wisely involved an agent over there, and when he called us to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief."

As they agreed to this amount, it was decided that each studio would present their case to Evans. So, one night in October, he sat in his study while four major filmmakers called, one after the other, to ask for the chance to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel.

Evans told me all this as we sat drinking coffee on a wooden porch above the leafy garden of his home. He said he had since turned down an offer to write the screenplay for "The Horse Whisperer." "It's all been like a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very tough, and I don't want to become an employee of these people who I like and who have paid me so much money. I'd hate to find myself writing a draft or two and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we'll bring in someone else.'"

He said he would be involved, but from a distance. The success of his novel had also brought new offers to support "Life and Limb," but he was no longer sure he wanted to make it. "I think I would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

Text: 'Young Masters Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to make a comeback in chess. Chess is now more popular among younger players. After 20 years away from the game, Fischer is playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game with a brilliant move, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in the best physical shape. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer himself helped make chess more popular, leading to a new era of professional players. Today, winning is the main goal for chess masters. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intelligence. The pressure of the game is intense: players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose. Now, games last longer and are often played without breaks, which benefits younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the top ten players in the world, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Much of the game happens off the board, with players preparing extensively before matches. Computers have had a big impact on chess. A small computer can store a million games and help players study their opponents. In one recent match, both players had teams working nonstop to find weaknesses in each other's strategies. The opening moves of a game are now studied in great detail, and being well-prepared can decide the outcome. Today, there are more top-level players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for modest prize money worldwide. Success requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. Losing concentration can lead to disaster. The chess clock adds to the tension, especially during the final moments when players have only seconds to make moves. This is not a time for deep thinking; it becomes a battle of nerves and determination. At the highest level, losing is very painful, while winning brings great satisfaction. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess masters must be ready to compete every day for 9-11 days in most tournaments, and there are competitions all year round. World championship matches are even tougher. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to stop because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about 10kg during the match. Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his sudden departure from chess in 1972 surprising. But it also made him a legend. If Fischer has returned for money, he will earn a lot. But if he truly believes he can still be the best, losing could be very disappointing.'

**Fame and Fortune: Interviews with Rising British Talent**

**A. Nick Grosso**  
Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, is a playwright with three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's a low-budget project, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be more than £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Interestingly, before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he admits. "It's set in a car, which I wouldn't do now because of the challenges. I knew nothing back then." Nick left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of its rhythm and rhyme," he explains. "Being around like-minded people was the first time I enjoyed an educational environment. It was very inspiring."

**B. Simon Pegg**  
Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has advanced in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and recently finished a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard, even performing in comedy clubs during his university days. "University was very theoretical," Simon recalls. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a traditional actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it's not. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." Simon has performed with the comic group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most rewarding. "Steve saw my show, and since I was a big fan, he probably noticed me imitating him," Simon admits.

**C. Ciaran McMenamin**  
Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became well-known as the lead in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show received great reviews, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says. "I can now choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was destined for success. Encouraged by his mother, he went from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But I decided to pursue it because I was good at it and loved it." Now, he is waiting for more recognition but is thoughtful about fame. "At 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you realize it's not about that. It's about getting respect for good work."

**D. Neil Taylor**  
Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released. "The record company talks about a smash hit, but I have no idea. If two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. I've been in some terrible bands, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E. Stephen Richards**  
Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won many prizes and awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and has been touring and giving readings for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express in a poem," he says. Stephen loved creative writing in school but became disillusioned with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theatre, I decided to go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving praise, moving to novels is a bold step. "There's a structure in poetry, so there's less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for bad writing. My main goal is not to produce work without caring about its quality."

A. Isabel, the main character in this funny novel, is an art student who loves historical romance stories. She is 31 years old and is looking for Mr. Right. Isabel thinks she looks good in jeans but avoids wearing them because she doesn't want to attract the wrong kind of people. She worries that her knobbly knees might ruin her chances of finding love. However, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a fast-paced style similar to early silent films, with chapter titles like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired.'

B. This story is about the beginning and near-end of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of Francis With, a smart but weak child. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town American setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. The story takes readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of dime stores, old cars, and the radio.

C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she wants his help to free her brother from prison. **Volunteer Tourism: A Discussion**

**A.** Volunteer tourism involves people traveling to other countries to help with projects like building homes or schools. However, volunteers often pay a lot of money to participate. This money, if given directly to local communities, could hire more workers than the volunteer can replace. This is especially true for gap year students, who usually don't have special skills or experience. Many studies question if these volunteers are truly motivated by a desire to help others or if they are more interested in gaining experiences that will help their careers. Despite this, volunteering can help people become more ethical and caring in their future lives and careers.

**B.** Volunteering can improve international understanding, help solve conflicts, and increase participation in global issues. It can also create international social networks among regular people. In this way, both volunteers and host communities benefit, contributing to a better world. However, if only wealthy people from rich countries volunteer, they gain international experience and career advantages, but it doesn't help those who can't access these opportunities. These volunteers might use the experience to advance personally, rather than truly helping the communities.

**C.** At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that benefits the volunteer more than the community. It can also be a way for wealthy people to boost their careers. At its best, it provides benefits to both volunteers and the communities, allowing for an exchange of skills and cultural experiences. Importantly, volunteering can increase awareness and commitment to fighting poverty, injustice, and unsustainable development.

**D.** Volunteer tourism fits with the idea of helping others in small ways. These efforts can seem positive because they avoid big government and business involvement. However, they also avoid the democratic process and reduce development to individual acts of charity, often not addressing the root causes of poverty. While volunteering is a good act, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can weaken the true meaning of development. The politics of volunteer tourism can ignore the real social issues and inequalities faced by many in developing countries.

Many of us use a radio to wake up in the morning, and we often need something to help us get out of bed. That's where the clock radio comes in. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models.

One model advertised a 'dual alarm function,' but it doesn't let you snooze and then wake up again. Instead, it lets you set two different wake-up times, like one for weekdays and one for weekends. This model is priced similarly to another one we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a good deal. You can fall asleep to your own music and wake up without news. We all thought the radio quality was excellent, but it's quite large, about the size of a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone, and he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.

This model was the most attractive and was our overall favorite. Paul Bridges loved it, although the clock on his test model kept getting stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its grey numbers on a green background. The snooze bar is wide, so you can tap it with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which was a problem when I had to read the 50-page instruction booklet. The clock has a backup power feature, so you don't have to reset it if someone unplugs it to use a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner. We all liked this feature, but setting it up was difficult, though we felt 'cool' and sophisticated once we figured it out.

Tom Granger thought the model with an extra built-in lamp was poorly made. You have to pull the light out of its socket to use it, which made him question its quality. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work, and the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The light is hard to position and only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but agreed the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer was loud and annoying, like an alarm on a submarine. Despite this, it's the third most popular model on the market.

Aimed at young people, with its bright colors and strap, this model appealed to Tom Granger and me. Tom liked it because it stands out and doesn't blend into the background. It was the only model we could set up without reading the instructions. However, the alarm can be off by 20 minutes, which Paul Bridges found ridiculous. He thought it was 'fiddly' and 'useless.'

The simplest and cheapest model scored points with Tom Granger because it was standard and took up little space. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found more intuitive. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed the buttons correctly. He admitted that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was basic, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model worked well, getting me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small animal known for the sharp spines covering its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not originally from America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they feel threatened, making their spines stick out to protect them. This defense works better if the hedgehog has many spines. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines because they have evolved to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger first and only roll into a ball if they have no other choice. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, usually under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in sports is challenging for everyone, but women often face extra difficulties. Training and competitions take up a lot of time, leaving little room for a normal life, so sacrifices are necessary. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we talk to some talented British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**
"It's an amazing feeling to fly through the air and land smoothly, but it can be scary. Sometimes you don't feel well, or it's windy and hard to see, but you just keep going. It's difficult to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses and get treated the same - it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was surprising because I'd never cycled before! I'm well paid as a professional, and cycling has many opportunities for endorsements. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I focus on cycling right now, rather than making money. I train at least four hours every day on the bike, plus stretching exercises, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is a cyclist too, so he understands the time commitment."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**
"Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools offer it. Most don't start until they're 19 or 20, which makes it harder to succeed internationally. Also, coaches usually stay for only a year or so, so there's no continuity, and the women's squad is often disorganized. But it's great fun, I love being fit, and there's a good social life."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**
"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world—I didn't realize how big it was then! Britain felt too small and safe. I was very determined and didn't like anyone controlling me. Now I am more tactful. Each walk has been different. Walking across Australia was the most painful experience I've ever had. I walked 50 miles and 21 hours each day with only three hours of sleep, in high temperatures, and with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to, because my sponsorship money was going to run out after 95 days. Men often think women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is seen as a higher risk."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**
"Some men have big egos when driving—you see it on motorways. When I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I reach a corner, men think 'I've got to beat her,' so I've had a lot of bumps! You have to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's very hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have always been seen as unusual. It's great that more women are taking up racing every year. For me, the appeal of saloon car racing is aiming for perfection, always trying to complete a perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**
"I get up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evening, I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes! There is a lot of nervous build-up before a race, and when you're racing, you really push yourself—you don't feel good if you don't. Several times I've asked myself why I do it. The answer is: a) I'm happier when I keep fit, b) I'm naturally lazy, and if I didn't make myself do this, I'd really be lazy, c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when an event is covered in the press, 90% of the article will explain the men's event, and 10% will say, 'Oh, by the way, so-and-so won the women's event.' The prize money isn't as good either, of course. But now we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission, so we're working on it."

Title: The Day I Met Picasso

Richard Cork remembers the time he, as an 18-year-old student, met the famous artist Picasso. Even from a distance, while Picasso was having lunch at a restaurant in Cannes, he was easy to recognize. Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van before starting university. He had run out of money and found a job painting boats. He loved drawing and had a sketchbook with him when he saw Picasso.

Picasso was known to be a private person who usually worked alone in the hills. So, Richard was surprised to see him at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Encouraged by a friend, Richard nervously approached Picasso to ask for his autograph. To his surprise, Picasso agreed and signed his sketchbook. Then, Picasso added a playful drawing on the page. The drawing might have been inspired by the surroundings, like the sea or the harbor.

Richard thanked Picasso and tried to have a conversation with him. Since Picasso's English was not good and Richard's French was also limited, an American woman at the table helped translate. She called Picasso "the Maestro" and was very enthusiastic. Richard told Picasso about his love for art and admiration for his work.

After showing the autograph to his friend, the friend suggested Richard go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Richard returned to Picasso's table and started drawing without asking for permission, fearing a refusal. Picasso noticed and made funny faces, making it hard for Richard to draw. Despite the challenge, Richard continued, feeling that Picasso was testing his determination.

Eventually, Picasso stopped joking and allowed Richard to study him quietly. Richard noticed how strong and alert Picasso looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. Picasso seemed younger than his age, with intense, youthful eyes. Even in a group, he appeared thoughtful and private.

When the American woman said Picasso wanted to see the portrait, Richard felt embarrassed but showed it to him. Picasso nodded in approval and then decided to draw Richard. In a few quick strokes, Picasso drew a playful version of Richard's face, moving one eye to his nose and capturing his smile with a single line. Richard felt like a character from one of Picasso's imaginative works.

Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but the American woman explained that Picasso said he had already signed once. Despite this, Richard felt lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention, which meant a lot to him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Spend More**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? We explain the tricks shops use to make you spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**

Supermarkets know that customers value fresh produce. They often place fruits and vegetables at the store entrance or have displays of house plants to create a fresh image. Some stores have in-store bakeries that spread the smell of fresh bread. The store's colors, like green, can also make things seem fresher. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, doesn't match this fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**

Where products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computer systems to find out which areas of the store are most popular. They put high-profit or fast-selling items in these spots. Products at eye level sell better, so manufacturers want their items there. Special offer bins attract bargain hunters. Stores also use 'complementation' by placing related items, like salad dressings near salads, together.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**

Supermarkets place basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by other tempting products. Chain stores do the same with popular items, placing them far from the entrance to encourage customers to explore the store and see other products.

**D. Less Sells More**

Chain stores have changed how they display products. The Next chain, for example, moved away from stacking items high and selling them cheap. Instead, they display fewer items to make them seem exclusive. This approach makes their stores look like boutiques, even though their clothes are mass-produced like their competitors.

**E. Tempting Totals**

Food shoppers often focus on the total cost of their shopping rather than individual prices. Supermarkets use this by offering a mix of low and high-profit items. They might sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as 'loss leaders.' More often, they buy in bulk to get discounts from manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**

In chain stores, customers buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. Pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing also helps reduce theft, as staff must record the sale to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**

Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully plan their lighting. Chain stores aim for natural lighting so customers see the true color of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to make fresh produce look better.

**H. Walk This Way**

Chain stores use different carpets to guide customers through the store. These paths, called the 'Yellow Brick Road,' lead shoppers through the store. However, not all customers follow these paths. Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths, encouraging shoppers to step onto the more inviting carpet in sales areas.

**I. In-Store Promotion**

When you enter a supermarket, you might see large photos of delicious food. In the U.S., some supermarkets use 'video trolleys' with screens that show ads as you shop. Sensors trigger ads for products near you, like ready-made meals. These trolleys target impulse buyers and can increase sales by about 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a 58-year-old mountaineer, is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston, aged 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record by sailing from New York to the Lizard in 10 days. Chris and Robin teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their book "Sea, Ice and Rock."

In 1979, while working on "Quest for Adventure," Chris contacted Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail, where Chris could teach him climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed, anchored, and then went ashore to try climbing. Chris was impressed by Robin's calmness in difficult climbing conditions. Robin had never climbed before, so Chris showed him how. Robin then used his own method to climb down, which was safe but different from what Chris expected.

During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a bigger version of their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin's leadership. Although the skipper usually makes all decisions, Robin involved everyone in the decision-making process. Chris found sailing boring and challenging, especially being at sea for days. He preferred land and wasn't handy with repairs, unlike Robin, who enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless, which was hard for him. The yacht was crowded with six people in a space meant for four, unlike mountain expeditions where you can have some space.

When they reached Greenland, Chris led the climbing part of the expedition. He found it hard to be responsible for Robin's safety, as a fall could endanger both of them. Climbing Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, was tougher than Chris expected. Robin, not a natural climber, impressed Chris with his determination. On their first attempt, they climbed for 24 hours straight and were exhausted. Robin trusted Chris completely, even when they had to turn back. Despite worrying about the boat, Robin supported trying to climb the mountain again.

The only tension between them happened on the yacht home. Chris was supposed to take a watch shift at 4 am, but Robin didn't wake him, thinking he could handle it alone. Chris felt Robin didn't trust him, but Robin reassured him it was a misunderstanding. By the end of the Greenland expedition, Chris realized that beneath Robin's tough exterior, he was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been with us since ancient times, in many different colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late 20th century, we risk losing this heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**

Humans have been eating apples since prehistoric times. In ancient Britain, people spat out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people even stored dried apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and not like the apples we know today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**

The French learned fruit-growing skills from the Romans, which they developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced some apple varieties, but most were not suitable for the British climate. The Normans introduced better varieties, and British monks continued to develop new apples. Many Western apples come from these varieties.

**Medieval Times (1200)**

In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, recorded in 1204, was the main dessert apple until the 18th century. Its cooking partner was the Costard, sold in Oxford markets from 1296. However, apple production declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and wars. More apples were imported until the 16th century when Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple cultivation. Harris brought back many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and started the first modern orchard in Kent.

**Settler Expansion (1750)**

By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed,' planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was known for his love of apple trees and his kind nature.

**Modern Apples (1850)**

Around this time in Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt discovered a new apple tree, which he named 'Hawkey.' It was later called 'Delicious' and became one of the most popular apples worldwide. In Australia, Maria Anne Smith discovered another famous apple. Known as 'Granny Smith,' she found a new apple tree in 1868 and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous globally.

**Uniformity Concerns (1950)**

Today, apples are grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most are grown commercially and come from just a few varieties, chosen for their appearance and ability to travel well, not for taste. This uniformity reduces the variety and gene pool of apples. While some gardeners in the UK preserve old apple varieties, the US has lost many apples from 100 years ago. Consumers now want more variety. We must protect natural diversity in apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.

Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on new and unusual destinations with unique itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.

Small Groups, Big Discoveries

Our groups average 16 people, allowing for a more personal experience. You can learn more about the places we visit and connect with local cultures. It's a stimulating experience for all travelers.

Various Modes of Travel

We use many types of transport, often on the same trip. This includes chartered coaches, local buses, trains, expedition vehicles, minibuses, boats, canoes, rafts, camels, light planes, and walking. Each trip adapts to the local environment.

Who Travels with Explore?

Our travelers are interesting people ready for new experiences. They come mainly from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are aged 25-55, with about half being couples and the rest solo adventurers.

Activities and Interests

Each Explore Worldwide trip is unique, so we have divided our adventures into 8 categories based on main activities and interests. These categories highlight special features of each tour, but many other factors contribute to the success of our trips, such as unique places, unusual encounters, and personal involvement.

Cultural/Adventure

Most of our trips have a strong cultural focus, emphasizing local cultures and historical sites. Destinations include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Yemen, Turkey, Greece, India, Bhutan, Thailand, China, Peru, Bolivia, Guatemala, and Belize. Short day walks to off-the-beaten-path sites are often included.

Wildlife and Natural History

Our wildlife safaris visit some of the world's greatest game parks, offering thrilling encounters with animals. In Africa, you can step out of your safari vehicle to explore. Activities include tracking gorillas in Zaire, bush walking in Uganda, climbing Mount Kenya, and canoeing on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, with some offering hotel stays. In Asia and South America, we stay in hotels or lodges for game viewing, like our tiger safari in India. In the Galapagos Islands, we stay on a small motor yacht.

Ethnic Encounters

A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, such as the Tuareg in the Sahara, the Maya in Mexico, or the Huli in Papua New Guinea. We travel in small groups to minimize cultural and environmental impact, promoting tolerance and understanding.

Easy/Moderate Hiking

Many trips include easy walks through countryside or village-to-village hiking, staying in rented or hotel accommodations. Destinations include Spain, Provence, Tuscany, Crete, Corsica, Greece, Morocco, Turkey, Bulgaria, Thailand, Bhutan, Nepal, and Venezuela. On longer walks, your main luggage is transported separately.

Major Treks

We offer major treks for strong walkers, sometimes at high altitudes. These treks take place in mountain ranges like the Atlas, Kackar, Himalayas, and Andes. We may stay with locals or camp, with support vehicles or porters to carry gear.

Wilderness Experience

Exploring remote wilderness areas is a thrilling adventure. We visit places like the Amazon Rainforest and the Sahara, offering a chance for a unique travel experience.

Sailtreks/Seatreks

These relaxing holidays involve traveling by local boats, such as felucca sailboats in Egypt or gulets in Turkey. We explore islands in the Indonesian Archipelago and the Galapagos by chartered yachts.

Raft and River Journeys

River journeys range from a few hours to several days, using inflatables or whitewater rafts. No experience is needed, and safety skills are quickly learned. Our river trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon offer insights into exotic jungles.

Richard Nerurkar, a top British 10,000-metre runner, visited a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. This camp is located in Nanyuki, near Mount Kenya, and has been his base for winter training for three years. However, he had never trained with Kenyan runners on their home ground until his fourth visit. During this trip, he competed in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. He was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. This was a great opportunity for him.

Training at high altitudes helps produce more red blood cells, improving oxygen capacity. This is one reason for the success of Kenyan runners. Richard's first race in Africa was an international cross-country race in Nairobi, the first of its kind on the continent. Although he finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan, he felt he had performed well.

Kenyan runners are known for their simple approach to running. They have an effortless style, a simple diet, and a relaxed manner, but they love to compete. The key to their success might be their training methods. Richard learned about these during his stay at the training camp.

The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and vegetation. The facilities are basic, with athletes living six to a room in dormitories. Their day includes three workouts: an easy morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. They cover about 40 kilometers daily, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers.

Life at the camp is simple. Morning preparations are minimal, and meals consist of tea, bread, boiled eggs, ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After the day's training, they bathe in streams from Mount Kenya's glaciers.

By the end of his stay, Richard appreciated Kenyan success even more. He realized it wasn't just about genetics, upbringing, or altitude. The simple lifestyle, tough workouts, and passion for success might be the real reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**

Advertising is struggling, and it's not just because of the recession. The decline started in 1989, before the recession hit hard. The main issue is that advertising hasn't kept up with economic changes. Advertisers focus on mass markets and mass media, but as more brands and media options have appeared, target markets have become smaller and more specific. Major brand campaigns should focus on these smaller audiences, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.

Think about your shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items, but only a few are advertised brands. Over a year, you probably buy only a few hundred different brands. For big items like cars, you might buy one every three years, and many people get their cars from their employers. You don't buy many clothes either, and most aren't advertised brands. Even when you include things like candy, medicine, and services, you likely don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.

Now, compare that to the 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. If we focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more on advertising, the average person buys only about 4% of them. This means 96% of advertising might be wasted because people don't buy those brands. When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about 6%, meaning 94% of commercials are wasted.

Most people think they aren't influenced by advertising, but that's not true. Waste is part of using media for advertising. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest, so some waste is unavoidable. However, advertising can still be cost-effective. It reaches many people to find the few who will respond, even if the advertiser doesn't know who they are in advance.

With better targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who might respond, but they can never know exactly who will. Even the best direct mail campaigns don't get a 100% response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every client. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they wouldn't need media; they could contact those people directly.

Any advertiser who gains one million new customers (2% of the adult population) is doing well. For example, top-selling soap brands would be happy with a million extra customers. An advertising campaign that wins over 2% of the population is very successful, but that's still a small part of the population. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message more precisely than ever before.

Title: Exploring Britain's Most Eco-Friendly Home

Charles Clover visits Britain's most eco-friendly home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This town is known for its ancient cathedral, Southwell Minster, which features 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen. The town also hosts Britain's greenest house, the 'autonomous house', created by Robert and Brenda Vale.

The Vales' house uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles sewage into garden compost, and heats the home using waste heat from appliances and body heat from the family and their two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional with a clay tile roof and fits well with the town's old buildings, even though it's in a protected area.

The house is very quiet inside because it is super-insulated with special windows. When you enter, you must take off your shoes, and the house feels very peaceful. On a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens windows and ventilation shafts to create airflow because the house is very well sealed, even the cats have their own special door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been interested in the environment for a long time. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s. They designed their house to produce no carbon dioxide and decided to use no mains water. They use composting toilets, collect rainwater, and filter it for drinking. They avoid using a dishwasher to prevent using strong detergents.

Robert explains that they wanted to show it's possible to have an environmentally friendly house without living in darkness. The house's design is modern, but the hall is tall like in medieval times. The Vales don't pay water bills, and last winter, they used very little electricity, costing about 70p a day. Soon, they will add solar panels to generate more electricity, possibly enough to charge an electric car.
