The only heating is a small wood stove, rarely used. In winter, the house stays warm because there are no drafts and everything is at the same temperature. Robert says people used to be comfortable at lower temperatures because of their clothing. He suggests people in old houses should live like they did in the past, but this idea might not be popular.

The house is simple and low-tech, with materials from local builders, making it cheap to build. However, commercial builders are not interested in this idea.

Text: 'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a logical and scientific person. However, in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies taken in a garden, he believed they were real evidence that fairies existed. He published these photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural beings. It wasn't until 1939 that the two women who took the photos admitted they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are undeniably beautiful, but the simple trick challenges the idea that cameras always show the truth. In fact, cameras can lie and always could. Today, we are familiar with using computer software to change our digital images, and it's a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the start, when cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

Blacksmiths have always been important throughout history. They work with iron, a metal that has fascinated people for a long time. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. For example, in the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were also made by skilled blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, blacksmiths were almost gone in Britain. Heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architects rarely used decorative ironwork. But in the past 10 years, there has been a revival. People are more interested in decorative architecture and creative interior design. Still, much of the work looks old-fashioned, with many products labeled as 'classical' or 'Victorian-style'. Trendy stores often sell rusty candlesticks with decorations.

Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths. A series of events aims to promote their craft. The first event is an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, believes we might be entering a new Iron Age. Modern tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to be more creative. The exhibition features about 250 pieces, from bookends to a spiral staircase, with prices starting at £90. Most of the money goes to the artists, but some supports the promotion of good ironwork.

Dawson's own work includes an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He describes his style as letting steel bend and flow when it's hot, like drawing with metal in space. Many artists are fascinated by iron because it is soft when hot but becomes hard when it cools. Susan May, a jeweler, finds this transformation magical. Ann Catrin Evans creates door-knockers and handles inspired by horror film castles. She likes that steel feels permanent and strong.

Iron has given people visual pleasure and a sense of security for a long time. It is likely that iron will continue to be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.

Title: The Day I Quit Smoking

I thought everyone would be happy when I quit smoking, but one of my colleagues was really angry. She said, "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't explain how I went from smoking a pack a day to not smoking at all in just four hours. It even surprised me. 

The session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to quit, and I didn't really want to. I was annoyed by the constant pressure from anti-smoking groups, and I still am. I had low blood pressure, a healthy family, and I didn't feel sick. I even got over colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking in Birmingham to write an article about others trying to quit. I told them, "I won't be trying to stop myself; it wouldn't be fair." I was there to write, not to quit, so I didn't expect their method to work on me. I actually enjoyed smoking; it made me happy. The counselor seemed to understand something I didn't.

We were allowed to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn't want to, and neither did the others. The messages about quitting made sense to me. Just like smoking had been a challenge against opposition, quitting started to feel appealing. The idea of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling, just for me. Could I conquer the world too?

In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical craving for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and only lasted for four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't a problem at all. I believed I needed nicotine to meet deadlines, but I was wrong. Surprisingly, the hardest part was spending weekend mornings at home without smoking, and it still is. I think smoking was a way to avoid boredom; it was an activity by itself.

Yes, I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is a challenge: eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theater break. These were all times when I used to smoke.

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel Prize, yet she is not well-known in her own country. Georgina Ferry, who is writing Hodgkin's biography, has noticed that many people in Britain are unaware of Hodgkin's achievements. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person. Her life mirrored significant changes in the 20th century, like the progress of women's education and the global spread of science.

When Ferry started her research, she read scientific biographies and was surprised to find that even famous scientists like Linus Pauling, who won Nobel Prizes in chemistry and peace, were not well-known in Britain. This lack of interest in scientists' lives is partly because some people think scientific biographies are boring. Peter Medawar, another Nobel laureate, once said that scientists' lives are often dull to read about. This view is common among publishers and booksellers, who often treat scientists differently from other biographical subjects.

However, this is changing. More scientists are appearing in public in different ways. For example, Richard Dawkins presents TV quiz prizes, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars on TV. These activities help people see scientists as real people, not just as researchers.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be serious and focused only on work, ignoring personal lives. But books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?" show scientists as real people with interesting lives. Now, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein are shown with their personal flaws.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. She solved the structures of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin, which won her the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1964. She also had three children and a husband who was often away. Her personal life may not seem directly related to her work, but it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.

Understanding scientific ideas is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort. It's unfortunate that many educated people don't recognize the names of important scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they are part of our rich cultural heritage.

Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a 'sixth sense'. She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers, whose wells have dried up, ask for her help. Margaret and her husband run a well-drilling business. They use modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers, but to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.

This skill, called dowsing, is the ability to find water, minerals, or lost objects underground. There are many ideas about how dowsing works. Some people think it involves physical forces like magnetism, while others believe it is more spiritual. One popular theory is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Dowsers, like Margaret, might be very good at sensing these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' or even smell water.

In recent years, when there has been less rain, Margaret has been very busy. At one point, people had to wait almost six weeks for her help. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She says, 'We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time.' Other customers include people with remote holiday homes and golf-course developers who need water for their facilities.

Margaret tries to find water 50 to 70 meters deep. She avoids drilling where farm waste could contaminate the water. The water she finds flows through cracks in hard rock, which helps keep it clean. However, in Cornwall, where she works, there is a lot of iron in the ground, so she has to be careful. Electricity is needed to run the water pump, so it's best if the well is near power sources.

To find water on large properties like golf courses, Margaret starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum over the map, and it swings when it is over a spot with water. After identifying possible areas, she walks over the land with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation and uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. The stick moves when water is directly below. It's important to drill exactly where the stick indicates, or they might miss the water. Her husband also checks the area, and they only drill when they agree on the spot.

Margaret's skill is not just an old tradition. Many people are interested in this mysterious ability. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This might explain why she is so good at finding water. Without this 'sixth sense', her family wouldn't be able to run their well-drilling business successfully year after year.

**We changed lives for a day!**

Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to try something different? We arranged this for four people - read about their experiences.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, a 23-year-old mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, a 30-year-old waitress at a busy London restaurant. Amanda had never been in such a lively place before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people, which was very different from her hometown. She had to learn quickly how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. It seemed easy for the other waitresses, but Amanda struggled and dropped the drinks. She was embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed it off, saying everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, a line of customers had formed, and Amanda felt nervous. Luckily, the orders were automated, so she didn't have to remember them. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she found the loud music hard to handle. She often had to ask customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and wanted to soak her feet. She was surprised to hear it had been a "quiet" day. Amanda realized waitressing was more tiring than she thought and required a bubbly personality and the ability to handle many customers. She was glad to return to her children, finding it easier than waitressing.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy was nervous but excited to be a "mum" for the day. She knew Amanda's daughters could be cheeky but thought she could manage. After Amanda left for work, Cindy had to dress and feed the girls, drop Sophie at school, and Katie at nursery. She expected some free time but had chores to do, like making beds and cleaning. After picking up Katie and shopping, she brought Sophie home, and the girls started playing loudly. Cindy hoped they would tire out, but they didn't. She managed to get them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to stay up. Cindy found it exhausting to look after two small children and realized how much responsibility it involved. Despite the challenges, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, a 42-year-old dairy farmer, swapped with Hilary, a 30-year-old primary school teacher. On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a treat. She was unsure about what to wear to school. At the school assembly, she hoped to blend in among 400 pupils. She helped with a maths class and a nature project, which was different from her school days. By lunchtime, she was tired but found teachers only have a short break. She attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson and a French lesson, where the children practiced on her. Finally, they had Physical Education, and Rosemary was exhausted. She found speaking in front of the class challenging. Despite teachers having more holidays, she preferred farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, surprised that Rosemary had been up for three hours. The farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 ewes. Rosemary also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream. Hilary spent the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk and packaging ice cream. At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped a fallen ewe. She realized how important it was to check them daily. After feeding the calves, she started milking, which took two and a half hours. Hilary found the day lonely and missed the children. She learned that farming is demanding, with little time off, and the income is irregular. Despite its romantic image, the reality of farming is tough.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new works. When you meet him, he seems even younger than his age, with a fresh and open manner like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a TV feature focused on his work and development, filmed in both the UK and Sweden.

Hardenberger was born near Malmo and started his career thanks to a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong's music, decided to give him a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and Hardenberger never stopped playing. His mother found a teacher for him, Bo Nilsson, a rising musician in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, who noticed his natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful for having such a dedicated teacher who was passionate about the trumpet and connected with players worldwide.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a primitive instrument with imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are the same. He believes in understanding these imperfections and working with them. From a young age, he had a unique sound, which he developed further. Unlike John Wallace, a great British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger always saw himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo performances, and collected all his records.

His parents supported his ambition to make a career out of trumpet playing. At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was considered too far and dangerous, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud advised against joining an orchestra, comparing it to gardening. Hardenberger knew he played better than others his age, but it was during his first competition at 17 in Paris that he realized he had a special gift for communicating through music. Thibaud suggested entering the competition for experience. Hardenberger learned the pieces for the first round and advanced to the second, where he knew most of the pieces. In the final, he faced a challenging concerto but enjoyed the performance, realizing that even though he didn't play perfectly, people listened to him.

Hardenberger's realism about his work might seem arrogant, but that's not true. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing his gift for communication, believing that trying to explain it might ruin it. He believes the power of music lies in its ability to move people.

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It's a special tale about human power, history, and humor. The author has skillfully created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is known for its humor and the author's unique way of seeing things. It also offers deep psychological insights, making it a challenging but rewarding read.

**B.** Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she wouldn't meet someone like Sheila, who is from a working-class background and takes care of her elderly father and grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe. After the court case, neither boy talks about the incident. Leo, who was a good student, won't explain his actions, and Joe becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's condition, while Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet. This meeting leads to an unusual friendship. The author is great at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives and captures the feeling that mothers often have of never doing enough.

**C.** This book, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of a remote Scottish Orkney island and its people over a long, quiet history. It connects this story with important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the dreams of a young character, Throfinn Ragnarson. Throfinn disappears at one point but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After a successful book, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle irony and sharp observations about family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life is a mix of vanity, charm, and kindness, and Rosie helps her in dealing with suitors and friends. By the end, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is taking over. The author is good at showing the sadness that lies beneath everyday life and highlights the unpredictability of events.

**E.** Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe how each person goes on a journey of self-discovery. They return home with their spirits lifted by their time on the ocean. The author uses striking images to explore themes of memory and awareness, which can be both confusing and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers: Rebecca Cripps meets five women who discuss their different professions: the highlights, the drawbacks, and their typical working day.**

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**

**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and start work by 8 am. I begin operating at 8:30 am. I operate all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most head surgeries take three hours, but some can last all day. I've worked ten hours straight without eating or using the bathroom. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. I don't feel stressed while operating, but I do worry about the next day's plans. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it's amazing and makes up for the failures. From 10 am to 1 pm, I have an out-patients' clinic where I explain the operations. I enjoy talking to patients, but comforting them can be hard due to time pressure. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I'm on call and always carry my pager. On holidays, I worry for the first three days about my patients, and I dream about operating at night. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**

**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I get up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, take the train, and arrive at work by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have meetings to discuss our work, problems, or if anyone needs help. We work in teams; mine has three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Only 10-15% of the work is design; the rest is production. I get a brief from the client, and if we're lucky, they have clear ideas about their goals, target market, and project form. I spend three to four weeks designing, researching, and developing the project. After presenting my ideas to the client and getting approval, we work on estimates and budgets, and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I coordinate with printers to ensure the job is done on time. I spend a lot of time managing people and need to communicate well with a wide range of people. Briefing them correctly is crucial. Once their work is done, I assemble everything and send it to the printers. Managing several jobs at once can be very stressful. Deadlines are always near, and no day is the same. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, and we try to go to the pub. Otherwise, I have sandwiches and work through. It's great when a client likes your designs, but disappointing when a job is rejected after hard work. I get home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later. I find it hard to relax when I'm busy."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**

**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually get up at 7 am, but two or three times a week, I meet long-haul flights and get up between 4:30 am and 5 am. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I have to watch my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and just snack during the day. People often ask me to recommend places, so I need to know my way around. Many jobs are pre-booked, so I can check routes beforehand. Not everyone is polite; some passengers are rude, but most are well-behaved, and I have a good relationship with regular clients. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving and not listening. The press has tried to get me to talk about clients, but I won't. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, and have to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**

**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I get up at 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mostly maintain gardens we designed and landscaped. We do some commercial jobs, but mostly private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. Around 11 am, we get hungry and go to a local café for a big breakfast. I often wish time didn't pass so quickly. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. The business office is at home, so when I return, I listen to messages and return calls. If someone wants their garden landscaped, I usually arrange a consultation in the evening. We specialize in using old materials and unusual plants to make gardens look old. Sometimes people have specific ideas that aren't great, but it's satisfying to see a garden bloom after landscaping. It's hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone. I never have trouble sleeping because the work is so physical that I'm always tired. I'm not very strong, but I'm fit. It's a tough job physically, but it allows creativity."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**

**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I'm the assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a retaining wall to prevent cars from driving into a quarry. I ensure contractors follow the schedule, specifications, safety systems, and minimize environmental impact. I coordinate site professionals and solve problems. Contractors start at 6 am, so my first task is to learn from the clerk of works what happened since I left. The rest of the day depends on this information. I review paperwork from contractors or answer design questions. Lunch is usually half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. When contractors are on break, it's easier to check the site. Checking their work can cause conflict, so we need an open relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but if something important happens, I act immediately. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I manage customer programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards program in major European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and answering emails. I handle all advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with our marketing team and advertising agencies to plan strategies and future developments. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to discuss issues. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10:00 am and go through the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day about campaigns or projects for artists, involving the press, marketing, and the managing director. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be constructive because it's important to the artists. I know if the sound fits our record label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs, producers, and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing and sales. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work at 7:00 pm at the earliest and often go to gigs, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. After gigs, I might visit an artist in the studio. My social life is mostly work-related, and I often get home at 1:00 am, where I listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**
I get up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I open the mail, check the diary for client visits, and wait to see who comes in. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and selling furniture, knowing it's going to a good home. We sell antiques priced between £1,000 and £6,000, buying from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work with gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette during coffee breaks to stay updated on the business and often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and it takes about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work set shifts, leaving home at 6:00 am for early shifts. At 7:00 am, I take over from the night shift at one of the four control positions in the tower. We rotate stations, working for about an hour and a half, then taking a half-hour break before switching stations. The team includes air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and a watch manager, and we control aircraft movements together. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing time to read up on new air traffic requirements. It's important to be alert in this job, so I don't hesitate to take sick leave if needed. The work is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually a general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**
If I'm on an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is at the till and coordinate staff lunches and breaks. I spend the morning helping customers and ordering books for them. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be frustrating when they expect me to gather many books based on reviews. Between 2:00 pm and 4:00 pm, publishers' representatives visit the shop, and I discuss new titles for the coming months. I decide how many copies of a title the shop might sell. When featuring a new title, I ensure it's delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the computer system, locking up, and going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving at 8:45 am. I contact our freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies abroad, warning clients of potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first executive preview is due online by 10:00 am, and the second by 11:00 am, so I quickly gather stories. I type them, send them to my editor for approval, and make any necessary changes before they are published. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events or stay updated. I leave work around 6:00 pm. It's hard to switch off, and I'm often awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and brings about change. Leadership is not about being tall or having a certain background, as early theories suggested. It's not just about being smart either. Pat Dixon, author of "Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace," says leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is important, and a good leader should speak clearly and confidently. Dixon says it's about having the confidence to say "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. **Recognizing Leadership Potential**  
John van Maurik, a director of a Leadership in Management course, believes many people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing, developing, and using these hidden talents. We are all born with some leadership ability, but we need the right environment to grow. While it's easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. Yet, leadership is now seen as essential for effective management.

C. **Reflect on Past Leaders**  
Think about the best and worst bosses you've had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these? The best leader motivated and supported you. The worst made you feel unimportant and kept information from you, blaming you when things went wrong. The first led well; the second just managed poorly.

D. **Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like working within set rules. Leaders create new paths. Michael Shea, author of "Leadership Rules," writes that a good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can transform a struggling organization, whether it's a company, a sports team, or a nation.

E. **Improving Leadership Skills**  
Whether you're a boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons:  
- Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find what you are passionate about. When you feel inspired to lead, use that energy and act.  
- Think of yourself as a leader. Recognize your ability to lead.  
- Collaboration is good, but sometimes firm leadership is needed. Try different styles. If you usually ask for others' opinions, try taking the lead. See how this changes the outcome.  
- Set goals and exceed them. Identify areas in your job where leadership can improve your effectiveness and career prospects.

F. **Developing Leadership**  
- Leadership doesn't just happen. It develops by taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and give feedback.  
- Don't assume your leadership style will immediately win over colleagues. It might even push them away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don't have to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be.  
- Be visible and accessible to those who matter. Remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know where your contribution is crucial and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made this intense Cold War thriller. It’s about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team remind us of the cool heroes in Howard Hawks' movies. The production design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and characters are not as strong. Despite the skilled filmmaking, the story feels like a typical B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, is interesting compared to Terrence Malick's new film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's is a more traditional war movie, often closer to the book. It focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's has its moments. The flashback of the soldier dreaming of his wife is done with a harshness that might work better than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
Loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, this entertaining swashbuckler is better than most musketeer adventures. Fabrice Luchini plays a great villain, a sneaky politician causing chaos. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is short. Daniel Auteuil, as an acrobat-turned-swordsman, is perhaps too serious for this fun film, but he has his moments. The filmmakers use costume-drama clichés with such wit and energy that it’s enjoyable.

**D. Character**  
This is a serious story set in early 1900s Rotterdam. The detailed production and costumes make the film look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is ruthless when evicting tenants. The main story is about his difficult relationship with his son, but the filmmakers focus too much on the period details, missing the dark and intense story.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This digitally re-mastered video shows director Leone's skills at their best. The sound editing is excellent, with every sound clear and loud. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's great music brings excitement. Morally, there’s little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach), as they all act without much scruple in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck features 'forty-eight international stars.' With four directors and 23,000 extras, it’s a big production. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for the invasion, feel slow for both the characters and the audience. Logistically, it’s impressive, but it’s better suited for the big screen. On video, it loses some of its impact.

**BOOK A**  
"Compelling Evidence" by Steve Martin is a gripping story. The narrator is a lawyer trying to start a new practice after leaving a big law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife, who is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, with the verdict uncertain until the end, and there's a surprising twist in the final pages. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B**  
"Curtains for the Cardinal" starts with excitement and follows Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy. He gets involved in political and religious intrigue and murder. We always believe he will solve the mystery and find the guilty. The plot is complex and the book is a bit long, but it's still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C**  
"File Under: Deceased" introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, created by first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah is a tax inspector who starts investigating when a strange man dies at her feet. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a local detective sergeant, Leah is determined and successful. She is a strong and versatile character.

**BOOK D**  
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk to remove drug dealers from a poor area in Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and there is more philosophy than violence. As always, Parker provides high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E**  
"False Prophet" by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate an attack and burglary at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and understanding of human behavior make this an entertaining mystery.

**BOOK F**  
"Blood Red, Snow White" is written by Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features a lawyer and a female client, but the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book mixes romance, money, and violence to create an exciting suspense novel.

**BOOK G**  
"Dead for a Ducat" by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher, who becomes a target. A funny group of characters gathers to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels this isn't right for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains, but this time the story is more of a farce and not as good as his usual work.

**BOOK H**  
"Fall Down Easy" by Lawrence Gough is his best book in a while. Canadian police are after a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow and skillful build-up of tension and the portrayal of the smart but troubled robber make this a standout detective novel.

At 34, Tim Pozzi decided to leave his good job and go backpacking. He wonders why he and others his age are making this choice. This summer, he quit his job, rented out his flat, and planned to travel in Southeast Asia for a year. You might think he's lucky, but he's nervous. It's not his first time traveling; after university, he spent two years backpacking in the Americas. When he returned, he wanted to do it again someday. But life happened—he fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. Over time, he realized he was giving up his happiness for money. Quitting his job felt like taking control of his life again. Now, he has no ties. Many of his friends are married with children, and while they wouldn't trade places with him, they envy his freedom. He's single and has no big career goals, so he feels he should make the most of his freedom, even for his friends' sake.

Why is he nervous? First, he has to make arrangements. How can he let someone else live in his home? How will he organize the rental? And he needs to decide where to go. He's a procrastinator and is already weeks behind schedule. He told himself to enjoy the summer in England and then thought about staying for the football season. Cutting emotional ties makes it harder. He's delaying because he wonders if he can still handle backpacking. Can he adjust to a simpler life? Will he fit in with younger backpackers? Maybe not. More Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to leave their lives behind and travel. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says people are realizing they can have adventures if they're brave, organized, and confident.

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, it's a chance to have fun before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny is willing to risk job security for the trip. He knows he might not advance in his career, but he thinks it's worth the risk. When he left his office, he threw his calculator into the river as a sign of defiance. For Matt, who just left the Army, a year of traveling was a time of change. In the military, there's a set way of doing things. He traveled to change this mindset and live better as a civilian.

There are many reasons to travel at this age, but some common factors exist. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says the workforce is more flexible now. More people work on short-term contracts, so if a contract ends, there's nothing to lose. Some companies even have career-break policies. They prefer employees to return rather than work for competitors. Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, says more people in their thirties are rethinking their lives. If they're unhappy, they don't just stick with it. They know opportunities exist, and jobs aren't for life anymore. Travel offers a chance to reassess life.

Is this wanderlust a sign of not accepting adulthood? Jennifer Cox thinks not. She says it's a sign of a better-educated, stable society. People want a balanced life, not just to pay bills. They ask, "Is this what I want?" Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn't think he's running away. He's running towards something he wants. But he feels nervous about leaving behind a comfortable routine, like going to the office and having coffee with colleagues. Tim shares Ben's concerns about leaving a stable life. He might not be traveling if his boss wasn't so difficult. Jennifer Cox says there's often a trigger, like a breakup or job loss, that pushes people to travel. Tim needed a push to start, but now he's excited about the next 12 months. Whatever happens, he'll be proud of taking this step, and he believes other older backpackers feel the same.

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her journalism career and felt disconnected from the new technology. She shares how she turned her home into an efficient workplace. When she turned 37, she realized she needed to restart her journalism career, which seemed outdated. Her resume showed she was stuck in the 1980s, using old technology like typewriters. She felt unqualified for jobs requiring desktop publishing skills, which she didn't have. She was a technophobe, confused by even simple gadgets like pocket calculators and video timers. 

She thought returning to work would be difficult until she entered a local newspaper competition and won a computer package. Her family received a laptop and a personal computer, and they quickly adapted to new terms like cyberspace and Internet. They started chatting online with people worldwide. The children stopped watching TV, and Georgina set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem. This allowed her to work from home and still take her children to school. The children were already comfortable with computers from school, but Georgina was hesitant, worried she might lose her work by pressing the wrong button. However, she learned the basic skills and found it logical and easy.

Georgina started freelancing for a magazine, writing two articles a month, and felt she had the best of both worlds. The computer helped her become organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets helped track income and expenses, and pre-formatted invoices saved time. For a journalist, being online meant she could research stories, ask for information, and discuss working from home with others worldwide.

However, working from home has downsides, like feeling isolated and being distracted by household chores. There are also arguments over computer use when the children are home. Many people are buying multimedia PCs for education, leisure, and work, avoiding the daily commute. A report on PC usage in UK homes describes the typical computer user as 38 years old, well-educated, with a personal computer, CD-ROM, laser printer, and modem. Georgina feels ahead of the curve and dreams of emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or publishing her own magazine from home. The possibilities seem endless.

The Tartan Museum

The new Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh has modern buildings that look very different from the historic area around it. Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened to see if the inside was as impressive as the outside. The museum is hard to miss with its large yellow sandstone tower and unique design. When the building was first completed, people had mixed feelings about its modern architecture. Some loved it, calling it a "masterpiece," while others were not so sure.

Inside, the museum tells many stories about Scotland's history, using important historical objects. There is a timeline to help visitors understand the order of events, but it doesn't limit the displays. The museum doesn't let national pride overshadow its treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels.

The main question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to visit more than once. Dr. David Clarke, who is in charge of the exhibitions, wants the museum to be enjoyable for everyone, not just experts. He believes in showing the truth about history, so there are no imaginative recreations of the past. Instead, the museum uses explanation panels, captions, and some multimedia to tell the stories of the objects.

The museum's design is impressive, with galleries that flow into each other and plenty of natural light. There is also a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a group of young advisors from across Scotland. Although the children wanted to ride through the displays, they got a hands-on center instead.

On the top floor, there is a Twentieth Century gallery with objects chosen by Scottish people and others that have impacted life in Scotland. The Prime Minister suggested an electric guitar, while others chose televisions and favorite toys. This gallery will change every three years.

Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that objects can vividly show the past. The modern architecture of the museum works well from the inside, but whether it fits in with its surroundings is still up for debate.

The end of print newspapers might take longer than expected. Transition is a comforting word, suggesting a smooth change from the present to the future. However, the shift of newspapers to the online world is uncertain and uncomfortable. Many believe it will happen because print sales are dropping while online visits are increasing. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen print sales fall by 8-10% in a year, but their websites are more popular than ever. 

Despite this, the situation is not straightforward. The World Association of Newspapers reports that global newspaper circulation actually rose by 1.1% last year, thanks to growth in Asia, even though sales in the West declined. News magazines, which we might expect to struggle, actually saw a 5.4% increase. 

Books show a similar trend. E-readers like Kindle are selling well, but the value of physical book sales only dropped by 0.4%. It seems people are using both digital and print formats. 

The idea that young people are abandoning newspapers is exaggerated. Nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read national dailies. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, print sales fell by 10.8%, but in Germany, the decline was only 7%, and in France, just 3.1%. 

These differences suggest the situation is more complex than expected. In the US, online advertising was supposed to support digital newspapers, but digital ad revenues are now falling. Many US newspapers have introduced paywalls, but the best way to attract paying readers is to offer both print and digital access together. Print is still important for selling online subscriptions, and print ads earn much more money than online ads. 

This is challenging for newspaper companies because maintaining both print and online editions is costly and complex. However, newspapers still have a strong presence in print, and being noticed online is more difficult.

**Photographing People**

People are very interesting to photograph. A picture with a person in it is usually more engaging than one without. However, photographing people well can be challenging. Besides technical and artistic skills, a photographer must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, the camera can make people act unnaturally.

**A. Grouping People**

Avoid straight lines in group photos. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances, or on different levels. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so all faces are visible, or take the photo from a higher angle.

**B. Posing for Pictures**

People often act unnaturally in front of a camera. They might become stiff. Help them relax by suggesting they find a comfortable position, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**

Don't pretend you are not taking a picture when you clearly are, as this can create tension. Most people will agree to be photographed, even if they protest at first. They might become self-conscious, so you may need to guide them. A photo can be ruined if the person is looking away aimlessly.

**D. Eye Contact**

A photo is more impactful if the person looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, but they don't have to smile. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**

Instead of direct eye contact, the person can focus on something in the picture. This might be easier for them, and the viewer can follow their gaze. Candid shots are interesting, and the person's expression is important.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**

Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about the person in a photo. A laughing child makes the viewer smile, while a sad expression can make the viewer feel sympathy. Look for familiar expressions like shrugs, winks, or thumbs-up. They are a universal visual language.

**G. Situation Interest**

Photos that show a person with their background can be more interesting. Make sure the background adds to the photo and doesn't distract from the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person stand out against the background.

**H. Interaction**

When people are interacting, there are great photo opportunities. Couples, mothers and babies, or teams working together make appealing shots. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake, or wait for an expressive gesture.

**I. People and Places**

Many photos of people are taken on holidays to show the places they visit. To improve these photos, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the whole scene. Ask people to stand close to the camera so they are in the foreground without blocking the background. An elevated camera position can help balance the people and the place in the photo.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**

Decide why you want to take the picture. If it's to remember someone you met briefly, ask them to pose against a nice background. Family photos can be boring if they are all formal poses. Candid photos of events are more lively and capture natural moments. A spontaneous picture can bring back memories better than a posed one.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist. This means she paints pictures that trick the eye into seeing something that looks real. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her and her work.

Sarah Janson is different from many artists because she doesn't sign her paintings unless someone asks her to. She believes the artwork is more important than the artist. She is very modest and sometimes acts like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes her a bit shy during interviews. She doesn't like talking about herself and feels uncomfortable being photographed.

However, once she relaxes, the interview becomes fun and interesting. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But she wasn't satisfied with illustration, so she started working with a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to try trompe-l'oeil, and she loved it. She decided to start her own business, even though she wasn't sure where it would lead.

Sarah's skills in observing details, which she developed through illustrating, are very important for trompe-l'oeil. She believes that no one can teach you trompe-l'oeil; it's something you learn by observing life. She always feels like she is still learning and believes that if you think you've mastered something, it's time to stop.

Sarah is honest about her weaknesses. For example, she says she can't paint bread well because it looks like grey concrete. She also struggles with math, which was a problem when she had to calculate measurements for a big project at Lulworth Castle. She often questions herself and doesn't openly acknowledge her talent, sometimes talking about herself in the third person.

Despite her modesty, Sarah's work is exceptional. Her trompe-l'oeil paintings are much better than those of many others who have tried this art form. She has completed many important projects for both companies and private clients. Her work is often inspired by architecture, like a dining room painted to look like a Venetian palace or a painting that makes a hallway look like it leads to more rooms.

Sarah knows that trompe-l'oeil must do two things: it must trick you and then keep your interest by engaging your imagination. She believes the art should be personal to the client, and she enjoys working with them to create ideas. Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working on their projects.

Sarah appreciates her clients, especially those who give her creative freedom. They are happy with her work, which keeps her busy, even though she doesn't like to boast about her talent. She repeats that she doesn't like to shout about herself or her work, preferring a more subtle approach. But her work is so impressive that it deserves more recognition, even if she doesn't seek it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

**A** The way we are judged at work is changing. It's not just about how smart we are or our training, but also how well we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging is important for hiring and promotions. It helps predict who will excel and who might not. These skills are crucial for future job opportunities. They are different from what we learned in school, where exams were important. Now, it's assumed we have enough intelligence and technical skills. The focus is on social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These are called emotional intelligence.

**B** Job security is less certain now, so personal qualities are more important at work. These qualities have been called different names like 'character' and 'soft skills', but now we call them 'emotional intelligence'. This means being aware of and managing our own and others' feelings, and using them to guide our actions. Emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. It's not just about being nice. Sometimes it means being honest, even if it's uncomfortable. It also doesn't mean expressing all feelings freely. Instead, it means managing feelings so they help people work well together towards a common goal.

**C** Many businesses now see emotional intelligence as important for management. The more complex the job, the more emotional intelligence matters. Without it, technical skills and intelligence might not be used effectively. Some people succeed despite lacking emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and team-based, companies that encourage teamwork and customer focus have an advantage. Emotional intelligence is becoming essential for success in every job worldwide.

**D** Unlike IQ, which changes little, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life experiences. Studies show that people often get better at managing emotions, motivating themselves, and improving social skills over time. This growth is sometimes called maturity. Emotional intelligence can be learned, and we can add these skills to help us succeed, especially when job stability is uncertain. While emotional intelligence isn't a magic solution for struggling companies, ignoring it can make everything else less effective.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important events, but social media has changed citizen photography even more. News often breaks on social networks, so some journalists use them to find images when events happen quickly. Unfortunately, some reporters have used user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. Even though there is official advice that images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or if there is a strong public interest, people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, so UGC is clearly important for the future of the media. However, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media must make sure people are properly rewarded for their work and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West: Acupuncture**

Acupuncture is a practice that is 2,000 years old and comes from traditional Chinese medicine. This system includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, physical manipulation, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat many conditions, but it is most known in the West for helping with pain relief. Some general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly for this purpose.

**A. What is Acupuncture?**

Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the energy of the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ, and many smaller ones that carry Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is disturbed, the body can become unbalanced, leading to weakness or illness. An acupuncturist will try to find where the Qi is imbalanced by checking your pulse, looking at your tongue, and assessing your overall appearance. They will also ask about your medical history, current health, and lifestyle habits. Acupuncture involves inserting fine needles into the skin, sometimes with added warmth or pressure, to stimulate the flow of Qi.

**B. Acupuncture Points**

The points used in acupuncture are related to meridians and may not be near the area of pain. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is moved, either by hand or with an electro-acupuncture machine. This feeling indicates that the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian. There are over 300 main points on the meridians, with many more used less frequently.

**C. Scientific Explanations**

Even without accepting traditional Chinese principles, Western doctors recognize that acupuncture can relieve pain. Scientific explanations suggest that acupuncture might work by stimulating nerves to block pain signals from reaching the brain or by releasing natural pain-relieving substances called endorphins.

**D. Types of Pain Treated**

Many people with chronic pain turn to acupuncture as a last resort. It is commonly used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and post-surgery pain. Acupuncturists also claim to treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**E. Modern Use of Acupuncture**

Although acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, using it instead of anesthesia during surgery began in the 1950s. This helped convince some doctors outside China of its effectiveness. In China, acupuncture is used in various surgeries, including tonsillectomies, caesareans, and even open-heart surgery. It can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or with drugs. It is said to eliminate pain, but this varies from person to person. Acupuncture anesthesia has no side effects like conventional anesthetics, such as nausea, and recovery is quicker.

**F. Effectiveness of Acupuncture**

Clinical trials for acupuncture are challenging to conduct, but those that have been done show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists agree with this success rate but acknowledge it doesn't work for everyone. For chronic pain, it usually takes six to seven visits to feel significant relief, though some improvement should be felt after two or three visits.

**G. A Different View on Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine view pain differently. Acupuncturists take a holistic approach, considering not just symptoms but also underlying weaknesses in Qi and external factors like weather conditions. They ask if the pain is worse in cold, heat, damp, or wind, and whether it feels sharp, dull, throbbing, constant, or burning. These factors help decide how to treat the pain with acupuncture, unlike the typical approach of a medical doctor.

**H. Traditional vs. Modern Approaches**

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others, including many GPs, prefer scientific explanations over traditional Chinese theory. Traditional acupuncturists believe that only by using traditional methods can deep changes be made for a longer-lasting cure, which is hard to measure in trials. It's important to choose an acupuncturist carefully, and they should refer you to a medical doctor if further investigation is needed.

P.D. James, whose full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, is a famous crime writer known for her complex and imaginative stories. She has a calm and authoritative presence, which might make you think she could have been a headmistress if she hadn't become a writer. However, she admits that this authority hides her shyness. Her famous detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is somewhat based on her, or how she imagines she might have been if she were a man. Like Dalgliesh, she prefers to work alone, especially when writing, needing complete privacy.

Despite her success, with 12 major detective novels read by millions worldwide, she is modest about her fame. She enjoys the psychological novels of her friend Ruth Rendell, who writes under the name Barbara Vine, and also reads works by women authors like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, as well as male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh.

P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first novel, "Cover Her Face," was published. Born in Oxford and raised in Cambridge, she met her husband, Connor Bantry White, there. Life was challenging after her husband returned from World War II very ill. She had to work long hours to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped by taking care of the children during those tough times.

While working full-time for the National Health Service and later at the Home Office, she used her organizational skills effectively. Her work included administration for forensic science research and dealing with juvenile crime. During this time, she became used to seeing corpses, but it was the structure of writing crime novels that interested her, not death itself. She always wanted to be a writer and saw detective stories as a way to learn how to write serious novels. Writing these stories allowed her to bring order to chaos and show the value of life, even if the life in question was not lovable. She believes that nobody truly likes violence.

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you might be asked for a handwriting sample. Your handwriting could help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, also known as graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Researchers say it can help identify certain illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and show psychological and emotional issues. More companies are using handwriting analysis for career guidance and during interviews. Many large companies hire graphologists to look at the handwriting of people applying for important jobs. However, most doctors and psychiatrists are still unsure about the value of graphology.

Patricia Marne, a graphologist with over 20 years of experience, believes doctors should take it more seriously. She thinks handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting can show social class and intelligence. It can also help assess mental ability, whether someone should focus on arts or sciences, and if they have a tricky or honest character." According to Ms. Marne, graphology can be useful in spotting criminal tendencies: "Criminals often have messy handwriting, usually poorly shaped. Many come from difficult backgrounds and have stopped developing emotionally. This can appear as childish handwriting or writing over letters multiple times."

Ms. Marne can tell if people are honest, manipulative, or reliable workers. "Young male offenders often have high ascenders, showing they live in a fantasy world and dream of success. Graphologists can see if violence might happen, if the writer is under too much pressure, or if there are psychopathic tendencies. Handwriting can even predict potential suicides." She also says heart and lung problems can appear in handwriting. "You can't diagnose from one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. But if it changes over time or becomes disjointed, or if there's a break in the signature that wasn't there before, it could mean something serious has happened." A big emotional upset can also temporarily change a signature, she says.

Ms. Marne explains that handwriting can show other psychological traits. People whose letters form 'threads' instead of clear shapes are often clever and tricky. Those who write mostly in capital letters might be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity and low energy. Original handwriting, different from standard script, shows confidence and artistic talent. Disconnected writing is a sign of a loner. Very small signatures show inhibition and an inferiority complex; circles over the 'i' are a call for attention, and crossing the 't' heavily over the whole word shows intolerance and a patronizing attitude.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, along with empathy and intuition. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a proper science, and she thinks this will happen soon. "It's more accurate than psychoanalysis because you can learn a person's whole history, including emotional crises, without asking questions they might answer incorrectly."

While this sounds interesting, there is little solid evidence to support these claims. Some psychiatrists are very critical. They say handwriting is a result of education, artistic skill, and the type of writing taught, and it has no other meaning.

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies people's working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple; no central heating, no mechanical ventilation, and windows open directly to the street. It's hard to see why this space works, but the small, dynamic team seems happy. They adjust to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, much like they do at home. This might be the key: a team of seven people has created a happy, homely work environment without outside rules.

Ergonomist: The furniture here is mismatched and often causes bad working postures. Chairs are old, most aren't adjustable, and many are broken. Despite this, the staff have a varied work schedule, which they control, including office work, client meetings, and presentations. This variety reduces the risk of fatigue, boredom, and muscle problems.

Occupational Psychologist: Staff enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. They said their office was 'just the right size'—small enough to know what colleagues are doing, but large enough to work alone. I found the office attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.

Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office may not be exciting, but it is comfortable and the staff don't dislike it. The air quality and maintenance are good, helped by a No Smoking policy.

Ergonomist: The company has already used an ergonomist. Chairs are excellent, and lighting and computer equipment are good. Space is good, but the layout could be better. The environment is impersonal and dull, with grey, bare walls.

Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for at least five years, and relationships are satisfactory. The office could improve if desks were arranged to share information more easily. Success stories or upcoming projects could be displayed on the walls.

Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: This office gets mixed reactions. It feels like being in a glass case, viewing and being viewed by many similar setups. Despite smokers and non-smokers in a small space, the air doesn't seem stale. Even standing 1.5 meters from a smoker, you can't smell the cigarette.

Ergonomist: The office is very standard and uninspiring. Desks are just adequate. Not all chairs meet requirements, but this is user choice. Computer screens are often on small desks with lowered keyboard shelves, which is outdated.

Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and are well-served by technology. Many communication awards are displayed. The wood-colored panels and brown carpet give a slightly serious effect. The office is busy.

Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: It's hard to say anything good about this building. The air-conditioning is poorly controlled, causing big temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and most people have inadequate desk space. The office is very dusty, with many places for dust to settle. The roof collects dust, which can fall on people below.

Ergonomist: The furniture looks more suited to a carpentry workshop than a high-tech industry. Most chairs are not good for keyboard users, especially those shorter than 1.75 m. Many chairs are old, lack adjustment, and have armrests that prevent users from getting close to the desk.

Occupational Psychologist: Old brown chairs, dirty carpets, dust, and dirt everywhere. There's a lot of room for improvement—the place needs a good clean-up, individual success should be more recognized, and air conditioning needs immediate improvement due to many smokers. Few conversations were happening when we visited; everyone seemed stressed and focused on deadlines. The company needs to adopt team-working policies.'

Chewing Gum Culture

Chewing gum is popular and classless, with Americans chewing 12 million pieces every day. Learn how this ancient habit became a big business. Each stick of gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered a food and must meet the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration. Modern gum is mostly synthetic, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and improve texture. 

In the past, the ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, found mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women used mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Amero-Indians in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, spruce gum was sold in the eastern United States, becoming the first commercial chewing gum there.

Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla commercially have failed, so synthetic alternatives were developed as the market grew. Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, have a tough and dangerous job. They travel long distances in high humidity to collect sapodilla sap. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects, including the chicle fly, which lays eggs in their ears and nose. Chicleros climb trees with just a rope and an axe to collect the sap, which is then boiled into bricks at forest camps. Life at these camps is hard, with a basic maize diet and local alcohol.

Despite the harsh conditions, chicleros worry about their jobs. The U.S. used to import 7,000 tonnes of chicle a year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers use synthetics to cut costs and meet demand.

Gum producers are also finding new ways to market their products. Gum is said to help you relax, boost energy, and reduce tension. Soldiers in both world wars were given gum. The biggest claim is that gum reduces tooth decay by increasing saliva flow, which neutralizes plaque acid and provides minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride. Research continues on new textures and flavors, with glycerine and vegetable oils used in the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural ingredients. In the U.S., 137 square kilometers are used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calm of an English country house with Indian cultural elements. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The facilities are simple, with hot water provided in buckets, but this simplicity adds to the hotel's charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I discovered it by accident while climbing. After a long climb down from a glacier, I was surprised to find this hotel in such a beautiful, wild, and high location. It was amazing to arrive tired and find luxury, with someone playing Cole Porter on the piano.

**C. MAURITIUS - BEACHCOMBER PARADIS HOTEL**  
Located on a peninsula in the southwest of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is in a quiet area. The road to the hotel winds along the coast past empty beaches. The hotel is large and offers free watersports, but you can find solitude on its nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, when everyone leaves, you can sit on the beach and feel far away from everything.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia is in a dramatic Caribbean setting. It is quiet and remote, standing 1,000 feet high with open rooms that look out between the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The style is colonial, with mahogany and greenheart wood furniture and four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
This hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a peaceful escape from Istanbul's noise. The islands are an hour away by boat and have no cars, only horse-drawn carriages and beautiful 1920s wooden architecture. The Splendid Hotel is a landmark, painted white with red domes, resembling a hotel from the French Riviera. It is a bit worn but still charming.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, is a beautiful 17th-century chateau. Surrounded by a moat with swans, the chateau has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds. One room even has a billiard table. There are special weekend rates that include breakfast, dinner, and complimentary champagne.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel in Nairobi is a comfortable place that avoids flashy luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers resting from safaris. Some guests decide to stay longer after seeing the gardens, rooms, and dining options. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city center, and is a great place to watch the African sunset with a drink.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido in Portofino was first visited by the Duke of Windsor. Many famous people have stayed here, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet wealthy businesspeople. The hotel, once a monastery, is still splendid, with simple but delicious food and beautiful Persian rugs.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they meet certain standards. Christopher Middleton watched her inspect the Globe Hotel. Right from the start, things were not going well for the hotel. The receptionist was busy on the phone and did not notice Sue, which was a mistake. Sue has seen this happen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. The Globe Hotel is special because it has three red stars, meaning it is one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide Sue works for. 

When Sue arrived, she noticed problems. The entrance from the car park was through an empty door with a buzzer, leading to a long, empty corridor. This was not what she expected. Things got worse when the receptionist said they had no record of Sue's booking, even though most rooms were empty. The room they offered was not good. It was stuffy, and there was a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

Sue is known for being tough but fair. The next morning, after paying her bill, she told the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who she was. He was worried.
