Before Sue said anything, he apologized for a bad smell in the lounge, caused by a blocked drain. Sue suggested fixing the plumbing and not taking guests to that lounge. Greaves agreed and took notes. He had only been at the hotel for five months and hoped Sue's feedback would help improve the hotel.

Not everything was bad. Sue praised Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, a waitress, for their good work. The dinner was also good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating. Greaves asked what they needed to do to get three rosettes. Sue suggested not serving a dessert that falls apart. 

Sue's job is to give feedback that others might be too afraid to give. Sometimes people complain about her feedback, but she has to be honest. She also writes a full report for the hotel. Hotels pay to be included in the guide, so they value her feedback. Sue told Greaves that the hotel would keep its red stars, which was good news. However, another inspector would visit in the next two months to check if improvements were made. Greaves said he looked forward to it, though he didn't seem very happy.

Title: Conquering the Seven Summits

Doug Scott, a mountaineer, shares his experiences of climbing the highest peak on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He started this journey later in life and describes each climb in the order he completed them.

A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)
Doug and his partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave near the summit. Dougal started talking to someone who wasn't there, likely due to lack of oxygen. Doug also found himself talking to his feet, worried about frostbite. Despite the challenges, Doug felt confident with Dougal and managed to reach the summit.

B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)
In April 1976, Doug and Dougal faced the dangerous Mt. McKinley. They carried all their gear on their backs, a first for a new route on this mountain. The climb was tough, with cold and low air pressure making it feel higher than it was. They finally reached the summit, feeling victorious.

C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)
In September 1976, Doug and Paul Braithwaite planned to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up on Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle and struggled to find water. Eventually, they found a trail and reached the summit using the Umbwe route.

D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, joined a group climbing Aconcagua via the Polish Glacier. Due to time constraints, they took the standard route instead. They reached the summit and met climbers aiming to complete the Seven Summits, inspiring Doug to consider the same goal.

E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
In November 1992, Doug's team traveled to Antarctica. Despite harsh weather, they reached the summit in 8 hours. The experience was uplifting, even though visibility was poor due to a storm.

F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
In summer 1994, Doug's team climbed Elbrus. After acclimatizing, they used a cableway to reach 3,900m and then walked to a refuge. They faced strong winds and icy slopes but eventually reached the summit, realizing there was more to climb than expected.

G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
Doug's team aimed to establish a new route and connect with the local Dani people. Despite warnings of danger, they climbed the mountain, which is near a large gold mine. On May 12, they reached the summit, marking Doug's completion of the Seven Summits.

Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**

Style is important in our lives today, from clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares the latest fashion trends for this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**

Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He suggests choosing simpler styles instead of traditional, stiff, or frilly dresses. Ingham has been designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. Besides wedding dresses, he designs long evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a navy-blue summer suit, a staple in English women's wardrobes for the 20th century, but with a modern twist.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**

Sally Quail, who once worked for an art dealer, has no formal training in jewelry. She started designing jewelry when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Her pieces are popular with many celebrities. Her style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, inspired by 18th-century jewelry. Recently, she started using diamonds, saying, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**

Lily Grimson entered the competitive fashion world four years ago with only a basic art and design course. Two of her handbags were chosen for a major design exhibition. Her bags, handmade in the UK, are always noticed. They are glamorous, made from fine calfskin or heavy silk. A mix of style and quality makes a Grimson bag special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**

For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He says most women want natural-looking hair that is easy to manage at home. His unique approach ensures clients don't look like they just left a salon. However, his services are expensive, costing £250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. He has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**

Penny Pratt runs a small shop and is a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain and top restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and left her teaching job 10 years ago to try something new. Her simple yet modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She advises keeping flower arrangements simple and strong, with few leaves. For wedding bouquets, she says the flowers should be of the same species.

Text: 'Luxury and Modern Technology at the Merrion Hotel The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took almost two years to convert four large eighteenth-century houses into this hotel. This allowed the hotel to include the latest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. Although it cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He is very positive about its efficiency and features. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature, where staff can record guest preferences. Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can change the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust each room's temperature between 14°C and 25°C. Business guests will likely appreciate the technology in their rooms. MacCann expects about sixty-five percent of his business to come from this market. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future updates. Extra cables are in place for new technology. TVs are rented, not bought, so they can be replaced with newer models. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed. Despite all this technology, MacCann says they have tried to make the rooms feel comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large, well-furnished bedrooms. There is also a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. As with all luxury hotels, the food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a new, modern kitchen and has better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular restaurant without financial risk. With technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is likely to succeed.'

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her house is surrounded by a large garden, which provides many of her painting subjects. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread seeds everywhere. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures, especially along the two long flower borders next to the path that goes from east to west. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well. At first, Danny would say some of her ideas weren't worth it, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of individual plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She doesn't arrange everything at once. Instead, she paints one flower at a time, which can take a few days, and then adds another flower to the painting. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. She is also fascinated by how flowers change as they decay. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being in water for a day. At first, they might look boring, but they twist and turn over time.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She wasn't interested in gardening back then and didn't like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She preferred wildflowers because they grew in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of flowers to paint, she finds it hard to work in the garden. She hired another gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

In March, strong storms hit the Brackham area, knocking down many trees. In the town, two big lime trees in the old market square were lost. This change upset some of the town's more traditional residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, who leads the local police, would have been upset too. However, during the storm, Pelham was very sick with bronchitis for the first time in his life. When he first felt a headache and chest tightness, his wife, Molly, urged him to see a doctor. But Pelham thought the police needed him, so he ignored her and kept working. This only made him forgetful and irritable. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. She took him to get antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed. On Thursday morning, when Molly told him the walnut tree in their garden had fallen, Pelham couldn't understand it. That evening, he asked if the house was damaged, felt relieved when it wasn't, and went back to sleep. By Saturday, the antibiotics worked, his fever went down, and he got up. He was shocked to see the walnut tree gone, which changed how the living room looked. The Pelhams' large house had a big garden, which made it feel private. Pelham didn't regret buying it. Before, the walnut tree was part of the view from the living room. It didn't make the room dark because there was another window, but it created nice light patterns that hid the old furniture they brought from their last house. Without the tree, the room was very bright, showing the worn furniture. The view was now of the tall house next door, with its ugly purple bricks and pipes, and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams. "Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham said to Molly. But Molly, standing in the doorway, seemed happy. "I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

Living in the Valley

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first realized the dangers in the surrounding hills that could threaten us. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall and within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. On the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we only felt sudden strong winds; trees moved, but the branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had a reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but they did not trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that was the biggest threat. It reminded us of what could have happened if the water from the hills had not been controlled by dams many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These grey clouds spread over the valleys, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling and getting close to a dangerous level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like Niagara Falls, as water surged over the dam and into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the water rushed down to its lower parts. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream was wild under the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it near our home, fiercely hitting its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Fortunately, our hopes were answered as the dam held and the waters began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river often flooded the nearby villages. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine; the large amount of water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with only occasional overflows. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and be amazed by the river's power. Thanks to this, we feel our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

Film Critic Mark Adams reflects on his last ten years working as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for The Front Page was his first real job. Before that, he had done some reviewing of novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and anything he was asked to do for the radio. This is how he met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also wrote for radio and TV. Tom hired him, but Tom wasn't mainly a journalist, or he might have been more careful in choosing his staff. 

At first, Tom's idea was to have a team of critics handle art forms that didn't need specialized knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have a weekly lunch to choose what artistic material to cover, with guests to make it sociable. It felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and Mark was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. It felt just as likely that a millionaire wanted to help him personally and was pretending to employ him. This showed his lack of self-confidence. The first time he saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with one of his reviews, he didn't know where to look.

Tom's plan for a team of arts critics never happened. It was a good idea, but they didn't meet as planned, so everything was done by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to link a reviewer with one subject area, so Mark chose film. Without Tom's initial push, they wouldn't have the current setup, where Mark writes a long weekly piece, usually on one film. This way of working suits him well. He wouldn't have been interested in the usual film critic's role, which involves reviewing every film that comes out. That routine would make him bored quickly. He would soon be sighing, "What insulting rubbish must I sit through now?"—a common feeling in screening rooms worldwide.

The space he is given allows him to expand his argument—or forces him, in a dull week, to make something out of nothing. But what is his role in the public space? He assumes people choose films based on the stars, publicity, or director. There is also loyalty to a 'type' of film or its opposite. It's rare for someone who hates westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romance fan to avoid a romantic film because of reviews. So if a film review isn't really a consumer guide, what is it? He doesn't feel responsible for being 'right' about a movie. Nor does he think there should be a set number of 'great' and 'bad' films each year. All he has to do is present an argument. He's not a judge, and he doesn't want to be.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because she thinks it's fun. A teenager who loves endurance sports is looking for a training partner. The partner should be a sports enthusiast, preferably female, and interested in distance running, swimming, and cycling. The triathlon is becoming a popular Olympic sport, attracting large crowds who are amazed by athletes who swim, cycle, and run without stopping. But why do these athletes push their bodies so hard? And why would a talented 17-year-old, with good grades, choose this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears hasn't yet learned the usual phrases athletes use about personal satisfaction and mental challenges. She says, "You swim 1500m, then get on your bike while still wet, which makes you cold. After cycling 40km, you have to run 10km, which is tough when you're tired. But it's great fun and worth it in the end."

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14 and won the junior section, though she was the only junior. Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Despite having the second-fastest swim and the fastest run, she didn't place well because she got lost and cycled 20km too far. She cried during the run but didn't give up and is determined not to.

Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. He says, "I tested her fitness, and she worked so hard on the running machine that it threw her off. She gave it everything, but unlike most people, she didn't stop."

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. She was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running but slower in cycling, so she's working hard to improve. She's trying to convince her parents to buy her a £2,000 bike for national races, even though they are already paying £1,300 for her trip to the World Championships in New Zealand.

Her intense training has made her a bit of a loner. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not into parties. After two hours of swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I keep in touch with my teammates by phone and letters." What do they talk about? Not boys or clothes, but their race times.

Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon 'sprint,' which is shorter. She wants to enter even tougher events. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It's surprising, isn't it?

Amanda Roy writes about her love for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It's a world full of passion and excitement. But if you don't love an object, don't collect it. People have been collecting since ancient times. Early humans collected pebbles for their beauty and wore them as necklaces. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for their shapes and colors.

I've been collecting all my life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. At six, I went to a school in a remote, windy part of England. My parents took me to a local museum filled with historical collections, which fascinated me. Many adults share this interest in collecting. Some people collect because it gives them control over something in their lives. For me, it's simply enjoyable.

Famous collectors include the Duc de Berry in France, who had a 'room of wonders' with items like coconut shell cups and Oriental china. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You don't need to be rich to collect. I've collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great determination. I once convinced another tulip collector to give me a tulip, which was later stolen by another collector.

I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. This collection was lost in a house fire. The next day, I saw the remains of my furniture and collection, unsure which loss was worse. I'm interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon once owned by a king or poet gains value in markets. As small objects become popular, their prices rise. Toys from the 1950s are now valuable investments, especially if you kept the original boxes. Unfortunately, I threw mine away.

**My Line of Work: Four People Talk About Their Jobs**

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. This means I plan and design the exhibitions and promote them. First, I learn about the exhibition topic and talk to experts to decide on the main themes and goals. I choose which objects and pictures to display. It's important that visitors understand the exhibition, so I plan interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to ensure everything is safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start my day at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I prepare new maps and documents for students to learn the routes needed for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are figuring out the best routes, using the correct one-way streets and turns. I help when there's a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. As the test approaches, I challenge students by giving them a route and then telling them to find another way because of a road closure. This helps them think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the coast and mostly work from home. My job includes answering phone calls, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. Sometimes, I visit our main office, but I usually work on the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers. I take them out to sea to help them understand marine life better, which often changes their perspective. I love my job because conservation is my passion, but working for a charity means we always need more money, so I can't do everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My job is quite varied. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and manage the stock of about 300 books we publish. We maintain high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which need careful replies. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with an enthusiastic team, which makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there's too much administration, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, the four of us spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who bought the house, the Malseeds, have added to the building, but they did it very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, though my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school because Dekko Deacon sounds nice. He and Strafe went to school together, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it's quite a coincidence. "How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive because she's usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium." These are the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of details like that, while her husband handles redecoration and repairs. "Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said, entering the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He smiled with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur led us to the rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not too long because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June, Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns and others taking the cliff path to the seashore. In the morning, we'd do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then return in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, this routine had developed. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.

Title: 'Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy'

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is in her second year working as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. Known as Pilch, she works for a company that provides cooking and cleaning services for visitors staying in chalets, which are wooden houses typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl isn't a long-term career but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.'

Sarah doesn't live at the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After the guests finish breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she says is the worst part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She tries to ski as much as possible and can be on the slopes until 4:30 p.m. on a good day.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she doesn't nap because it makes her too tired. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans up and loads the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant, but some weeks don't go quite as well.'

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. They usually start at Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps end the night at Dick's T-Bar. However, Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you don't want to be cooking breakfast with a headache.'

On Sunday, work starts earlier because breakfast for departing guests must be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet thoroughly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions, which she thinks is due to the mountain air. Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski equipment and gets a ride back to the chalet from the ski shop staff. Then it's time for dinner again, and maybe a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale-skinned girl, visited Seymour's factory one day. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was six years older. Rita was wearing overalls and big shoes, and her wiry hair framed her pretty face. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or giving a short tour if he thought they were serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago. Seymour had shown them how he made gloves, especially Marie's favorite part, the laying-off table. This is where the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. Marie, as a little girl, was fascinated by them and called them 'pancake hands.'

Rita asked Seymour, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" He replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She kept taking notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, "They come to the tannery. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it into the right kind of leather for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. So did I, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" Rita said, "Not yet." Seymour offered, "Well, you need to visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I'll arrange that for you if you'd like. They're primitive places. Technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. It's said to be the oldest industry with remains found anywhere. Six-thousand-year-old tanning relics were found in Turkey, I believe. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. I told you it was an interesting subject once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; he's the one you should talk to. Start him off about gloves, and he'll talk for two days. That's typical: glove makers love the trade and everything about it. Have you ever seen anything being manufactured, Miss Cohen?" Rita replied, "I can't say I have." Seymour asked, "Never seen anything made?" Rita said, "I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child." Seymour laughed. She had made him laugh. She was eager to learn, with a good-natured intelligence that reminded him of Marie. Marie would come home from school full of what she'd learned, remembering everything and writing it down in her notebook. Seymour said, "I'll tell you what we're going to do. We're going to show you the whole process. Come on. We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you're going to watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

Text: 'Is it really a dream job? Chris Arnot talks to four people with jobs that seem amazing to find out if they really are. 

A. Raquel Graham
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. However, she has one small problem - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax,' she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so cramped with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring paperwork - organizing the schedule, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning trips, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job. She met the manager of a pop group by chance, which led to a job offer behind the scenes. She also took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a personal assistant.

B. David Brown
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy. You would too if golf was your passion. But there were some downsides. Caddies get a small fixed fee plus a percentage of the golfer's winnings. The average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, and much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first worked for the golfer Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the golf course.' His accounting skills were noticed by European Tour Productions, and they made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes the statistics of each day's play from cards brought in by the caddies. Television commentators, golfing magazines, and the golfers themselves all want these results.

C. Martin Fern
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try the food at the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember for the rest of my life than buy a microwave.' His talent as a cook led to an offer to write a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director at an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper called to offer him a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession.' He still does all the cooking at home and tries to keep his weight under control by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

D. Dick Prince
'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. 'Before that, I always loved words and enjoyed using them, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which was my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That's what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not an early riser, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend another couple of hours typing out the morning's notes - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter rather than on a laptop. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that's the part of being a writer that I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles covered the yard all the way to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, all the boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed on the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to follow him. Still laughing, he watched them from the roof, looking scared, but one by one they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes until one of them said, "Let's go up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they all went up and started jumping off again until only Michael was left. The others were below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the roof, nervous and smiling awkwardly, wondering why it seemed so much higher now. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried counting to ten and jumping, but it didn't work. He tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. After a while, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted, and when he didn't move, they started to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for almost an hour while the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet from sweating nervously. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump, then got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled seriousness, but Michael, with his dark, unhappy face, barely heard her; he was still thinking about the boys laughing at him.

Text: 'Careers Advice Are you unhappy with your job but unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change jobs are now turning to careers advisers. You will need to write a short history of yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a summary with career suggestions and possible retraining options. I decided to try Career Analysts, a big career advice organization. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school exams. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. It was important to remember that it wasn't about passing or failing. The psychometrics involved tasks like finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the tests, I had a long talk with an adviser. Using the test results and our conversation, he made a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, though I was a bit upset to learn I did poorly in scientific and technical tests. It's probably good that I never became a nurse. However, it was comforting to hear that I made the right choice in journalism. Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to step back and review my career,' says Donna. Some results surprised her. 'I didn't know I had a talent for design. But I had to consider the cost of retraining in design against my financial needs,' she says. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use my existing skills and move to a job better suited to me than insurance. Now, I work as a Public Relations officer. I might have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me see clearly what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to several friends, who are all happy with the service.' Some people feel they wouldn't have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led 26-year-old Juliet Greene to make big life changes. 'After working for a bank for six years, I found my job boring and needed a new challenge. I didn't know what I wanted, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course this year. The advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the fee. I'm much happier and more positive now.' However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I was at a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many new ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary cut or a lot of retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice.'

Title: 'Enjoyable Visits to the Dentist?'

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you'll notice bright paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch for patients. Jerome explains that half of the people only visit the dentist when they are in pain because they are scared. To change this, he has created a friendly environment. He doesn't wear a white coat because it reminds people of pain. Jerome believes dental visits should be relaxing and even enjoyable.

This idea is surprising for many who think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome says that if people are relaxed and entertained, they will forget their past bad experiences. One of his new techniques is using virtual-reality headsets. His practice was the first in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while Jerome examines their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth. Many patients enjoy this part of their visit.

Another important aspect is the pleasant smell in the office, which is more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome says that he wants people to feel with all their senses that this is not a typical dentist visit. The usual dental smell can make people nervous if they are afraid of dentists. I found the gentle smell in the office very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. Relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of treatment is the most important. For example, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a bit strange at first, but it is not painful if people are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. He discovered that making things easier for patients also makes it easier for dentists. He believes his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a change towards less formality in British dentistry.

As a patient arrives, Jerome offers him a cup of tea, asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this luxurious treatment, and it's easy to see why. The office feels more like a fancy beauty salon than a regular dental practice.

Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a huge global business. During Easter, people in the UK spend over £230 million on chocolate, with 8% of all chocolate sales happening at this time. Only at Christmas do people consume more chocolate. Large-scale chocolate production began in the last century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans due to a spelling mistake from the 17th century. The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish preferred it with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread across Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company later added milk solids, creating milk chocolate. At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to add some French style. But Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, launched as Dairymaid in 1905, became popular with clever advertising linking it to the healthy milk from the English countryside. Now, chocolate consumption in Britain is about four bars a week per person. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers, like turning chocolate bars into ice creams, soft drinks, or desserts. Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke, at 83 years old, has become very skilled in his art. He still wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells, a skill he has perfected over the last ten years. 

As he shows me around his apartment, he says, "Tell me if I am boring you." However, Peter is not boring at all. He is enthusiastic and charming, and his work is beautiful. He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace and says he doesn't mind if they don't sell because he loves them. He never planned to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to have an exhibition. Five years ago, he had his first exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened yesterday.

The pieces are quite expensive, with some ornaments costing around £2,000. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he doesn't set the prices and is open about how high they are. He believes no one else in the world makes work like his. The gallery owner told him that once he stops creating, everyone will want his pieces because there won't be any more.

Peter wishes he had started this art earlier in life because he feels he could have created even more amazing things. Although he still has many ideas, he finds himself more physically limited now than when he began. Despite this, his work is far more sophisticated than the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. He describes himself as having a "miniature mind," which has led to intricate boxes covered in tiny shells, small pictures made from shells, and baskets of realistic flowers.

Peter has developed his own methods and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says his work seems to create itself, but the detail, color, and symmetry show careful planning.

His search for beautiful, especially small, shells has taken him beyond the shores of Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming the environment. He argues that people walking on the beach destroy shells faster than he can collect them, and the sea breaks them up too. He would never collect shells with living creatures inside or dive for them. Once the shells are empty, he sees no harm in collecting them. His work often turns these shells into something even more beautiful than they were naturally.

Text: 'The Schoolgirl Model When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, she's probably studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw finds out more. 'I'm afraid Kira will be a little late,' the receptionist at the agency told me. 'Oh, fine,' I said, 'no problem.' I had been trying to convince myself that all the negative things I had read about models were not true, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to mind. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided a visit to the hairdresser's would be more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she would be rushing. She could be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions. But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira was not dressed in expensive designer clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work, she explained, and apart from looking incredibly young, her mother was a normal mum - visibly proud of her successful daughter. Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was not planned. It was her older sister who decided that she should enter the model competition. 'She saw the competition and said I should go in for it,' Kira remembers. 'I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway.' When the call came to tell her that she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work. Kira now finds that one of the hardest things she has to do is manage her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers have become used to having a star among them. 'They're really proud of me,' she says. However, a few unkind people at her school are rude about her success. 'They say I have too high an opinion of myself.' This kind of remark must be hard for Kira to deal with, since there can't be many people as successful as her who are less self-important. But she says, 'They assume that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident - not in a bad way, but I'm able to stand up for myself more.' As a busy model, though, her social life is obviously affected. The Select agency can call at any time and tell her that she is wanted for a job the next day. 'If my friends are going out together, I can't say I'll come, because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get broken, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, "Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us".' Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. And not many people can say that before they even take their school-leaving exams. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the outstanding beauty that seems certain to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies: 'I'd like to do what you're doing.'

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat to find valuable metals. They believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "We are finding a lot of gold as we dig; we just need to go a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

The Maddens have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold worth millions in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing the land and finding small pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission to dig, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, it seems difficult, but we have some people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread, the idea of finding gold excited both locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would bring more people here if they are right, but I hope millions don't come and damage the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when many people worked in hundreds of mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed recently. However, individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, like finding hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University as a lecturer and researcher in marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. When she is not teaching, she goes on dives to study underwater volcanoes. She uses a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to dive three kilometers down into the ocean. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can easily touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they can't stand or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency, they can press a panic button, which releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested this yet, and it might not be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. The water flows at one meter per second and is 350 degrees hot. Rachel was only scared once, during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest parts of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing things no one else has ever seen. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in real life was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind couldn't handle any more foreign schedules, money, or languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year, and the year after that. All I needed was one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Once you've learned to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds never feel the same. The train's rhythm helps you sleep deeply. Carrying everything in a backpack makes you travel simply, and you might even burn socks that smell too bad or throw away books when you're done with them. This carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be ignored. All you need is one of those tickets. This system lets young people travel through many countries quickly, which is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn't realize how much we could do with this ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But the idea of constant travel was too tempting. There was always another country to visit, just a bit further away. And the extra miles cost us nothing. We weren't completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents. We made our own schedule and only saw the most accessible sights. It was a chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I was proud that sometimes all I saw was the view from the station. We were there to enjoy ourselves, just like other Inter-Railers we met. We shared train floors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place that was just a name before. It's like the city didn't exist until you arrived and saw it with your own eyes. Only by seeing Europe, watching the landscapes change, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what's there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. That's why other people's holiday photos are boring. While the train trip won't show you anything new in the world, it's a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail gives people the best chance to realize this, though it didn't happen for us right away.

Arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your baggage is missing is very disappointing. At best, you might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you could be in a different climate and have to wear clothes that are not suitable. Airlines don't often say how many bags they lose, but regular travelers will eventually experience this problem. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and no airline can guarantee that your checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes.

Here's how the system works: Airlines ask passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between flights, and these are also set to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights, causing the baggage system to fail. Human error or accidents, like a torn-off destination label, can also cause issues. These problems are more common at large transfer airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport managed over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.

To avoid losing your baggage, choose direct flights when possible and check in early. If you must change planes or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Include your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who knows a lot about kingfishers. These are beautiful blue-green birds that live near streams and rivers and eat fish. The area where they live is full of soft colors like greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher moves quickly and brightly through this scene, leaving a strong impression even though it is small.

Charlie fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He can't quite explain why he loves them so much, but they are part of many legends. In Greek mythology, a kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top turned blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. Scientifically, kingfishers don't have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, their feathers reflect light in a way that makes them look blue or green, depending on the light.

Many wildlife photographers are fascinated by kingfishers. They are shy around people but can be watched easily from a hidden spot. Charlie's first hiding place was an old blanket he used to cover himself while waiting for a kingfisher. The bird came close, but it took him four years to get a good picture. During this time, he spent as much time as possible near streams with many kingfishers, even skipping school, which affected his grades.

Despite this, his passion for kingfishers was noticed. At 16, he became an advisor for a nature magazine and later worked as an assistant to the editor. Eventually, he became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he dreams of making the perfect kingfisher film with just beautiful images and no words. He loves the simple approach and enjoys photographing parts of the kingfisher's wings. His photos show his deep feelings for the bird, but he knows there is more to his connection with kingfishers than his work can express.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected start in conducting when she asked to watch Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up replacing an absent assistant and was later invited to help with another opera. Manson, who is American, works with a London-based opera company that focuses on modern music. She is gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council, and has worked with Abbado on several projects since her first opportunity.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after failing in two others. He feels the timing was perfect, as earlier success might have been overwhelming. The competition opened doors for him, including working as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he worries about being labeled as just a "competition winner." He hopes that orchestras, like the English Chamber Orchestra, will continue to invite him back, as this is crucial for a lasting career.

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, founder of Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods in opera. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional. A turning point was taking lessons with Sian Edwards, who inspired her because they were similar in size, unlike her previous teachers. Kani appreciates the complexity of opera, including managing singers' personalities.

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting unexpectedly fascinating. He started as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's "Agrippina" from the piano at a festival, which was easier than he expected. He knew the music well and aimed to achieve his desired performance. Vignoles values his broad musical experience and is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys most.

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
Wayne Marshall's conducting career began in 1986 when Simon Rattle noticed him and recommended him to an agent. Marshall, now 32, quickly found himself conducting a musical in London, which was challenging. He dealt with relaxed musicians by being firm and clear. Although he hasn't formally studied conducting, he is confident and knows what he wants. He believes showing confidence is important, as showing worry can make things worse. Marshall is determined and has received support from others in the field.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you're planning to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try out some of the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns family**

Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old had a lot of fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is also a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the kids wanted to stay longer because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and scenery. However, the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus with its amazing trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is great for younger children. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small, which was a relief for us! The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, I couldn't sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge family**

We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then becomes exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all family**

The park advertises 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very impressive. Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, and the older children went on them several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. The staff were mixed; some were great with younger children, but not all were welcoming. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn't tell the kids we were leaving early.

Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women Share Their Stories

A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with her husband. They moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. Christine wanted a job she could do from home. She had experience with computers, so her husband suggested starting a design business. It was tough at first and required a lot of money. Christine was careful with spending and communicated with the bank manager about finances. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business is small, and local customers usually pick up their work.

B. Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no such jobs in the countryside. So, she started her own business, creating 50 different cards that she sells to museums. She works in a large room at home. The downside of working from home is the distraction of household chores. Her business grows through word of mouth, and she doesn't advertise. Maggy is cheaper than other artists, so people send her work from London. She misses exchanging ideas with others but finds more benefits than drawbacks.

C. Delia Turner has a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started eight years ago, and her business grew quickly, with a turnover increasing from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. She once managed six full-time workers but had to let them go due to economic decline. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and hires women who work from their homes. Delia adjusts her prices when needed and looks for new opportunities.

D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago because London was expensive and she loves the country. She enjoys flexible working hours, but 80% of her income comes from international deals, requiring her to take calls at odd times. The challenge is maintaining discipline to stop working. Tessa publishes children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt lonely because all her professional experience was in London.

E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop, with a turnover of £250,000 a year, employing six people, some part-time. She started at home ten years ago, focusing on healthy fruit cakes with quality ingredients. As demand grew, she began sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building for production, hiring a baker, assistant, and cake decorator. Meg now manages the business side and doesn't bake. Her biggest challenge has been financial, as they started with limited funds.

Meet the Amazing Watkins Family

The Watkins family is special because not only are the sons composers and prize-winning musicians, but their dad also makes musical instruments. John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers from South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, because he was very talented. However, buying a cello was too expensive. John thought about making one himself. He found out about the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and attended evening classes once a week for about three years.

After making a few violins and violas, John tried making his first cello. Paul, now 28, says it turned out really well. John made another cello for Paul later, which he used until recently. John has now retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling one to the famous American player Jaime Laredo was a big achievement for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano and then became interested in the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin, but he preferred the cello after meeting a cool cellist in his dad's music group. Huw was also encouraged to play music but chose not to play the violin. He is now 22 and is making a name for himself as a pianist and composer.

Paul's cello, made by his father, helped him win the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his father's cello until last year. Now, he plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. His father admits that the new cello is quite nice, but believes his own cello will improve with age.

Paul will soon be seen on television playing the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto for a new series called Masterworks. He says he will play it his own way, despite its famous history. However, Paul won't be able to watch himself on TV because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall the same evening. John and Hetty will need to be very organized to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules.

Text: 'Taking Care of the Countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden employed by the Trust to look after the beautiful areas it owns. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense. 'You also need to be good with people because you deal with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies all the time.' Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth got the job because of his local knowledge and farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. 'It's helpful that I still farm with my parents, so I understand farmers' problems. Also, they can't fool me about anything!' he says. His farming background also helps him handle the physical work of the job, like putting up fences, planting trees, and building walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. 'When I was young,' he remembers, 'I used to collect flowers, butterfly larvae, and old birds' nests. Recently, I wondered where I would find all those things now. It's clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault - they were just following government advice.' Gareth says that when he started, farmers and conservationists didn't get along. Both wanted things done their way. Now they talk and understand each other better. 'We're close to bringing them together,' says Gareth. Conservation is a big part of Gareth's work, along with allowing public access to the Trust's land, planting and maintaining trees, and meeting with the Trust's tenant farmers. 'My job is to make sure tasks are completed with little fuss and cost. I enjoy seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on paperwork and bills.' Gareth loves his job and, even though he's always on duty, he enjoys it, especially talking to the public. Most of them, anyway. 'I don't like the attitude of some people,' he admits. 'They come in, demand everything, and leave as if they own the place. Being nice to those people is annoying!' But as Gareth says, it's all about common sense. So if you have a lot of that and like outdoor work, you might consider becoming a warden like Gareth - but don't expect a job to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!'

Text: 'The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day leading up to next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's it.' 'My whole life is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. 'I'm on a strict schedule to get as fit as possible.' These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start well.'
