Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they're exciting to play. They have a lot of skill.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to push yourself to play every day, there's no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance.' In the fifteen years she has been playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game.' Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. I support and encourage the team.' 'From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned,' she says. 'I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player.' She will likely coach young players in the future, but right now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can you help a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always easy to know the best way to support and develop their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult to manage. While most schools can handle children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools, which are relatively new. These schools aim to create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, helping them develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend about one-third to half of their day on musical activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and second instruments), playing in orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours a day in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, though they can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students at these schools are boarders, meaning they live at the school full-time. This allows them to spend their formative years with others who have similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally gifted children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question whether it's wise to admit children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their main goal is to develop 'well-rounded and balanced individuals.'

There is a risk that separating musically gifted children from others at an early age can cause stress. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and offer help and advice when needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some are concerned about the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs aren't met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before considering a specialist education. Children who are also academically gifted might do well in a less specialized environment, like a school with a strong music department, or by combining regular schooling with music training at a junior department of a music college. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers and opportunities for orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be practical for families living far from major cities like London.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors and shapes, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well, and although Danny sometimes doubted her choices, he understood when she explained she wanted to paint them.

Susan usually focuses on painting individual plants in detail rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they are, but often she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, "I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one." Some paintings take years to complete. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the way flowers change as they decay fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being in water for a day.

Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She wasn't interested in garden flowers back then because she thought they looked fake, like silk or plastic ones in shops. She admired how wildflowers grew in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Now, her garden has many plants from distant countries, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed approach to gardening, like an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm.

With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of flowers to paint, Susan finds it hard to spend time gardening. She hired an extra gardener but believes that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Title: Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is in her second year working as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. Known as Pilch, she works for a company that provides cooking and cleaning services for visitors staying in chalets, which are wooden houses typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl is not a career but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.'

Sarah does not live at the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After the guests finish breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is the worst part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. 'On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.'

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she does not nap. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah cleans up after dinner and loads the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she chats with the guests, while other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant, but some weeks don't go quite as well.'

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. 'We usually start at Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps end the night at Dick's T-Bar,' she says. However, Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you don't want to be cooking breakfast while feeling exhausted.' Work starts earlier on Sunday, with breakfast for guests ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet thoroughly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. 'I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.'

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests needing boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it's time for dinner duty again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.

Text: 'Changing lives with a Stranger

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there.'

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. 'I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa.'

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, went with the TV gardening show Ground Force. 'I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, because of my shifts, I don't see daylight. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job.'

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. 'I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint doing some jobs, but I was surprised that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it left me with a great sense of satisfaction.'

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with Ryanair as cabin crew. 'I changed into the uniform, and I felt different—people suddenly respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult.'

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. 'I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see that some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier.''

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journeys**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past some amazing sea views. No matter the weather or time of year, it's always beautiful. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which goes across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I've worn it ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding preparations.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable—we were just given a day. We heard the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train appeared, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriages—some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite train memories as children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important to me. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming was on an old, unused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I went back last year, it was like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Are you trying to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, has some advice for you. Many readers ask us, "I've written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" The first thing you need to do is research the market and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Selling your writing requires understanding the publishing world. No matter what you write, you need to know the market you are targeting. The best way to do this is by reading as much as you can. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what publishers are looking for at any time. Keep updating your knowledge because new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. Publishers always want new writers, so we must give them what they want. 

If you're not sure what to write, start by exploring. For example, if you want to write short love stories, find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and learn what kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. Editors focus on what their readers want. Writers often ask me, "My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone, but the work might not be ready for publishing. Many new writers send their work too soon, before they are ready. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. 

When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while waiting for a reply. Write ten or even twenty more. Each one will improve, and you'll start seeing yourself as a writer. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I also suggest not showing your work to others in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.

On the last day of a difficult year, I was at the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. The station was busier than usual, with elderly couples and college students filling the space. A well-dressed, grey-haired man was going around asking people if they were traveling to Philadelphia. He approached a woman sitting alone and then a girl near me, but neither were going to Philadelphia. 

I noticed him because I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me. He seemed stressed and continued asking others. Finally, he found a woman reading a book who said she was going to Philadelphia. He asked her for a favor, explaining that his daughter was flying abroad from Philadelphia and had forgotten her passport. He needed someone to take it to her because he couldn't leave his wife, who was in a wheelchair.

I was skeptical of his story. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. The man was holding a padded envelope, which seemed suspicious to me. I silently warned the woman to be careful.

Text: 'Gary and Me The restaurant owner John Moore talks about his relationship with his son Gary, the famous TV chef. I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory and me feeling upset because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife focused on taking care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This has been very good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life. Gary was a very active child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined. He used to wake up even before me in the morning. If you run a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He would make over a hundred meals, and from then I knew he'd go into catering because he had talent. So when he came to me and said, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for my school course,' I sent him to a friend of mine who has a restaurant. Gary recently started playing the drums and now he has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary would be: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can do well. He understood when I told him: 'Gary, if you want to achieve something in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it might be too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students - who are usually beginners - were given work that should take a morning. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He had prepared everything. That's my son for you! In the end, he was helping other people. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. I'm very proud of him. I've always tried to tell him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it, because no one gives you anything. He's seen the opportunity he was given and took it with both hands. You know, you talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even ten percent of what you've told them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.'

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was very difficult, like finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often helped. But if you were new to Dublin, like Jo, you had no personal contacts to help you find a place. Jo had to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. Dublin was unfamiliar to her, and she felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going; everyone at her school assumed she would leave their small town. Many of her classmates moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle. But Jo was the only one from her year going to Dublin, and she was going alone.

Jo's mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel, which was run by nuns, so she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because hostels were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a whole week. Jo didn't know her family was still thinking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed perfect. Jo hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive.

There wasn't a long line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who had been rejected, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." "Oh," said Jo and continued up the stairs.

"Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." "What did she do?" asked Jo. "She didn't do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is to it? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, was a punk, which surprised Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but never talked to one. "I'm Jo, I work in the post office, and I called about the flat." Nessa said they were about to have tea and offered Jo a mug. One mug had "Nessa," another had "Pauline," and the third had "Other" written on it. "We'll put your name on it if you stay," Nessa said kindly.

Text: 'Behind the dolphin's smile People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside marinas, films, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are declining. Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, understand human emotions, and make us dream of freedom in the wild seas. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest have made us love them even more. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection plans could become a major wildlife disaster. There are forty different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two usually live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups, quickly passing ships. We know little about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show skin injuries, indicating stress. Dolphins have complex habits, making it hard to know why their numbers are decreasing. Overfishing, which is reducing fish stocks and threatening local fishing industries, also threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are removed by fishing, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing methods use huge nets that float or are pulled quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show they were caught in these nets. Waste and other substances in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they accumulate in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk rich in pesticides, passing the poison to their young. There is a recorded case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Another serious threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This may disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet understand.'

Text: 'GETTING FIT Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels chaotic and fast-paced. You might think this is just another article about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise. Exercise improves your muscles and changes your body shape quickly. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand or sit with good posture. Good posture is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. Exercise also helps prevent muscle problems that can cause injuries. It quickly improves areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It also makes your heart, lungs, and blood circulation better. You might have heard these reasons many times and feel bored, but here's something interesting: exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep problems. It also helps control stress and can improve some medical conditions. By now, you should see that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, or using weights. But remember, training too hard or with too much weight can cause injuries, so start slowly and carefully. If you're unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you. Good posture is important for improving your body shape. A stiff or sagging body doesn't look good and can cause minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling your head up to the sky. This helps lift your chest for better breathing and makes your body look slimmer. When standing, if your chest is balanced, you should be able to see your ankles. Stretching your muscles improves flexibility and helps you move easily. It also helps maintain good posture and prevents muscle injuries. Stretching four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit. So, stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.'

**In Their Natural Habitat**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? It's their search for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, finding producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman can be as hard as finding the animals they film. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost nonstop rain, causing many problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive tool so that when their vehicle gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull it out. Their teamwork has created some of TV's best wildlife films, like their popular film on leopards. Even while this film was being shown, they were already back in the wild, this time filming the shy jackal. 

This is common for TV partnerships. Film-makers have traveled the world to capture exotic wildlife since TV began. I talked to Newman about their partnership while he was briefly at a safari lodge. 'We sometimes argue, but we get over it quickly,' he says. Neither sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they see animals in the same way. 'When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But now we have a fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each morning, we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask.' Their meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. 'We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a worry,' says Newman. 

It's a tough life, but being alone in remote areas lets them get close to animals. Newman remembers filming a lion family where one lioness would greet their car as part of her routine. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift,' and two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. They spend four months on location to get enough material for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I worked well together from the start,' says Newman, 'because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create films rich in atmosphere that capture the true spirit of the place and animals, and that touch people's hearts. I believe it's better to evoke an emotional response than to appeal only to people's minds.'

Title: The Netball Captain

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met with Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra has a busy schedule as she prepares for the World Championships next month. She spends her day teaching at a local school and then trains in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location and asked if people stare. She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down, but that's it."

Kendra is dedicated to being in top shape for the Championships. This will be her fourth time competing, and it promises to be the largest event yet, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing at home means more pressure and expectations from the crowd. People want us to start strong."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "We've always beaten them, but they are talented and exciting to play against," Kendra notes. England is currently ranked fourth in the world, but the Championships will be challenging. "You have to play every day without rest. Unlike a series, you only get one chance in the Championships, so you must be ready."

In her 15 years at the top level, netball has become faster and more aggressive. "You train hard to win," Kendra says. "But after the game, we're all friendlier." The sport now uses a more scientific approach to fitness. "We must think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. As captain, she believes in having a strong mindset and leading by example. Her role is to support and encourage her team.

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might shed a tear, with her loyal supporters cheering her on.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, where she teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which is the study of chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she goes on dives in a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to explore underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can touch the two pilots. They can't stand or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, she has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, are many underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke, pouring out at one meter per second and at 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel was only scared once, during a dive with Americans. They were towing equipment when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest parts of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing things no one else has seen. After studying black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, body movements, how fast or slow we talk, our volume and tone of voice, and the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she remembers. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to present yourself in the best way." Many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but didn't even get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before applying again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from words, 38% from voice, and 55% from facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will believe the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job immediately. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't turn him down. So, he offered me a lower salary than I hoped for. I'm sure I could have gotten more if I had controlled my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it is important for a successful interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company's activities. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive impression and show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confused sentences. As she says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became less exciting and more of a routine. He didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but he was suddenly made redundant. Although he didn't receive a large payout, it was enough to start his farm. His big break came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, his reputation grew, and now he also sells meat by mail order. He is happy not to be in an office anymore, but he still works 80 to 90 hours a week and sells a product.

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. A career counsellor helped him, and he was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work for money. Ron and his family moved to the north of England, leaving their friends behind, but their friendships have survived, and many friends visit them.

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but the hours were long. She didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so she left. Some people thought she would get bored, but she never has. The key is to have deadlines because it's a fashion-related business with collections and seasons. She feels happier and less stressed now. She misses social interaction with colleagues but loves being responsible for her product. If something goes wrong, it's her responsibility.

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. He liked the excitement but didn't find the work rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. To change careers, he got qualifications in massage and was offered part-time work at the Life Centre. He has no regrets and now feels in control of his life.

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I've always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. At 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I hoped for sponsorship to help with training costs. I train at home during winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because of the great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics, which would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you often meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you can't party late at night. I don't mind that much, but I do miss sleeping in. It's worth it, though, because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out, and if there's prize money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship also got me a TV show about surfing, so I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in style, but we don't seek media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends who aren't in sailing. You can't focus on the sport all the time; it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I'm rarely recognized on the street, which I prefer. I get nice letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on the court. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with fans, but I still enjoy being recognized when I'm out. However, my last girlfriend didn't like the attention I got from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in sports and be professional. I'm okay with focusing on my game now and enjoying other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

Shopping with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says it's very hard because her children want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty if she buys them. But she also feels bad for saying no all the time. She tries not to take her kids shopping, but then worries they won't learn how to make their own choices.

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a shopping trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and they find it hard to believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when ads make products look so appealing.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often have to say no to their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to make people want to buy products, so even if they can't directly tell kids to ask their parents, the ads still have that effect.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to and which to refuse is a big source of stress for parents. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads, so they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in how they respond to their children's requests. Mike, a father of two, says he refuses to buy sweets for his kids because they're unhealthy, even though he buys treats for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent because his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without their children's demands might attract more customers.

Title: Luxury and Modern Technology at the Merrion Hotel

The Merrion Hotel in Dublin is a new five-star hotel that combines luxury with modern technology. It took almost two years to transform four large 18th-century houses into this hotel. This transformation allowed the hotel to install the latest technology for both staff and guests.

The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. However, for specific guest preferences, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature that records preferences.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. The Merrion has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can adjust the temperature within a small range themselves, or the front desk can change it between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers will appreciate the technology in the rooms. MacCann believes that 65% of the hotel's business will come from this market. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by installing extra cables and renting TVs, so they can be easily updated.

Despite all the technology, the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also has a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the Merrion must be excellent, as expected in luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He got to design a new, modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel benefits by offering a popular dining option without financial risk.

With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to succeed.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share how they do it.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann - Journalist and Author:**  
"I think excitement gives me energy. I need to be doing something challenging. Learning new things gives me a lot of energy. Anything with rhythm, like flamenco dancing, also energizes me. Dance is expressive and energizing. If you're bored, you can feel drained. Being effective, even in small ways, gives you energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey - Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel like a chore. Enjoying your work keeps you from feeling low, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep to feel good. When I only get six hours, I feel tired. Exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to find the energy to start. I do yoga once a week and try to work out at home. Exercise lifts my spirits. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 PM, so I think it's good to eat something then."

**C. Annie Nightingale - Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't eat healthily for energy; I think it's natural enthusiasm and positivity. I can't stand negative attitudes. I believe we should enjoy life and seize the moment. Enjoyment is important. You need to set goals and achieve things. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. Being around lively young people in my work keeps me energized. I love being busy and sociable. I enjoy taking photos and writing imaginary song lyrics for fun. It's a good mental release when I travel."

**D. Floella Benjamin - Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in my work and family life, and being positive helps. I love working with kids because they are resilient and give a lot. Energy is like a natural chemical that comes from interacting with others. Smiling at people and getting a smile back is thrilling. It's better than feeling sorry for yourself. I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise plan. My most energetic moments are playing with kids."

**E. Deborah Moggach - Author and Playwright:**  
"I love turning wasteland into a garden. I once transformed a concrete area by breaking it up and adding soil. It was better than any workout. Knowing someone wants to read my writing gives me energy. I find it hard to write without an audience. I also enjoy sneaking into private land, like a farmer's field, because it feels childlike."

**F. Katherine Monblot - Therapist:**  
"I believe you need to be interested in and respect what you do. I like taking risks and get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do is exhausting. I used to be on committees and didn't like the demands on my time. You have limited energy, so focus it on what's most important to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. People used these bone skates until iron skates were introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are very important, and you can only go faster as you get better. Your body position is crucial for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to center your body weight; this means leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It's quite simple, right? As you practice, you can slowly make your movements longer.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should learn. Even the best skaters fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when you fall. This reduces the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up. Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn the basic moves, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch good or professional skaters, you'll see how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To achieve this, you should regularly do exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should include those for the legs, back, and shoulders, focusing on the ankles and knees. After a long or intense skating session, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits heart and lung health and strengthens the body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard right now. I don't have time to watch TV, hang out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take each training day as it comes. When I'm extremely tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

**B. Annika's Mother**  
"Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents push their kids, and it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People often say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who sucked her thumb and hid behind me. Now, she's met people worldwide and gained confidence from her success."

**C. Sarah Stokes**  
Sarah started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I do it for myself. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

**D. Sarah's Mother**  
"Sarah's passion for horses started when she was 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to compete all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happiest on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

**E. Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting a big head. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like being embarrassed."

**F. Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father suggested it, and she loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to quit, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to hold her back because she's exceptional. If she has this talent, she should reach her potential."

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher joked, 'What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall at that age. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More and more tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We are now overcoming the effects of many years of poor diet, which is having a big impact. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals occasionally. This lifestyle is still followed by a few remaining tribes of hunter-gatherers. One study found that they ate 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, farming was invented, which had serious consequences. Most green areas on the planet have been taken over by farmers, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has negatively affected human health and body size. Over the centuries, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing of the New World, was actually a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. However, farming spread because it could support ten times more people than hunting and gathering. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the variety of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it also brings challenges. Heights have increased, but the world hasn't changed much. Standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers are constantly updating their product ranges. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot keep growing forever. There must be a natural limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, from the University, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller as an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies are better at keeping in heat.) Since the climate warmed, we have become slightly thinner and smaller, even with proper nutrition. As the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even more. In other words, the growth of human beings could be balanced out by global warming.'

Text: 'Studio Audiences What's it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people don't know much about them. When we see them excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Some think studio audiences are not very important. I've heard that even people in television don't respect them much. One cameraman said they treat them 'like cattle'. I thought studio audiences were just people wanting a bit of fame. But there's no typical studio audience. They come from all backgrounds and jobs. TV shows try to get different people for different shows. People who like watching TV at home might not understand why others go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio to watch something you can see at home? One idea is that people want to be on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. She said she came for a chance to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious about how shows are made. But most people said they came because 'a friend gave me a ticket'. Not many of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH - and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is 'more exciting', and Charlotte liked being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was just fun and a free night out.'

**Bruce**  
I don't like landscapes that are completely wild. I think the human touch is important. It's the same when I travel to other countries. I like beautiful villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its lovely valley. Cycling was a way to escape from school. I loved exploring the bare hilltops, the sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, the landscape felt familiar but different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. In a way, that was my first try at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by hobbyists. I always travel first class because it doesn't cost much more than the regular fare. The scenery isn't spectacular. The train moves across Romney Marsh with its sheep and alongside a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when our small train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers can see people at random times in their day, making a cup of tea, doing the dishes, or setting up a deckchair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into other people's homes. It's the ordinary landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. That makes me look more closely, to find something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and full of rocks, so there are not many people here. They attract a few brave surfers, but most visitors prefer to think about the majesty of the sea. The coast, which faces the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks you can combine with trips inland up beautiful damp valleys, full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who have some property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a landscape of wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are not many residents and not many visitors either. It's an unknown corner, empty and remote, and I like the feeling of space. I discovered the area by chance when I was a student, and since then I've visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he's growing up in a city environment.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. It was about finding pure peace and reconnecting with my English roots and coming home. I grew up in what is now called Sri Lanka, but at the age of twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's the place of my dreams. It's a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: A Day with Animals

We are a family that loves animals and enjoys having them around. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work, excited because she found a pine snake. She asked if we could keep it, and I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank for temporary animal guests, and we liked to look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and started cooking when I heard my sons shouting for help from their bedroom. I rushed in to find our cat, Domino, with a white mouse in his mouth. The mouse was a Mother's Day gift for me. Domino was running around the room, trying to escape with his catch, while the kids were waving their arms to stop him. I tripped and fell, and as I lay on the floor, I noticed the snake was escaping from its tank.

The room was chaotic, with the cat, mouse, kids, and snake all moving around. The dog was barking, and the pot in the kitchen was boiling over. I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the room. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived to old age.

Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I turned my attention to the snake. It was difficult to handle, but I eventually calmed it down. I carefully picked it up and took it to the garden, hoping it would leave. When I let go of its head, the snake didn't attack but instead wrapped around my shoulders like a scarf. My eldest child, DJ, explained that I was warm, and the snake liked that.

We all stood there, watching the snake. The children helped guide it to move on, and it slowly climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, summed up our feelings: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Send me a letter! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old way of writing letters is at risk of disappearing. Yet, for me, there is something special about getting a letter that no other form of communication can match. There is the excitement when it arrives, the pleasure of seeing who it is from, and finally, the enjoyment of reading it. Writing letters has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I would write to my mother. My mother also always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. Sometimes my father would write, and it was always a joy to receive his long, funny letters. Most of the letters from home were about everyday events with my parents and their friends. Of course, we also made phone calls, but it is the letters I remember most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. When I was young, I seemed to attract people who had to work or study far away, and I could only stay in touch by writing letters. But instead of hurting the relationships, writing letters seemed to make them better. I found that I could often express myself more easily in writing than by talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but how much better to have a year's worth of news! And it's even better when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters come from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked her for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would have missed out. As it is, we now have a regular correspondence. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success, however, came this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was amazed that a correspondence could last so long. The local newspaper even thought it was worth reporting on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother before me, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends of their own in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become another 'lost art'.'

Title: Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art in the Alps

In the French Alps, at Mont Bego, there are tens of thousands of ancient rock carvings. These carvings, which are about 4,000 years old, show images like cows with horns, fields, and gods. This site is very important for tourists, but the carvings are being damaged. Scientists are worried that the 36,000 drawings might not last for future generations because of this damage.

The site was once a place for prayer and worship. Now, as more people visit, the carvings are being ruined by graffiti and careless actions. Jean Clottes, who leads the International Committee on Rock Art, says that people think the drawings will always be there, but if the damage continues, they might disappear in 50 years. He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears them away. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. Others rub the drawings to make them clearer for photos, which damages them further. Some people even scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.

Experts have different ideas on how to protect the carvings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the best way is to close the mountain to the public, except for guided tours. He believes this will protect the site and allow research to continue. However, Jean Clottes disagrees, saying this idea is too extreme and would upset local people. He believes they should do everything possible to save the site without closing it completely.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He thinks the best solution is to let people visit but admits it's hard to stop them from causing damage because the area is large. He suggests charging a fee to help pay for guards, but there is no government funding available.

Annie Echassoux, who has also studied the site, is worried that as it becomes easier to reach, more damage will occur. She suggests roping off the area and providing guides. She insists that money must be found to protect the site because it is classified as a historic monument. If no action is taken, future generations might lose these ancient drawings.

Text: 'Climbing Walls: A New Way to Climb In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, you can climb anywhere, indoors or outdoors. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham's National Indoor Arena, the crowd watches as French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by his fingers on a climbing wall. This arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, and both events feature a climbing wall. This is possible because of new technology. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing angles. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, climbers needed to stay fit all year. When cliffs were unusable, they used brick or stone buildings to practice. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom. Soon, sports centers started building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges. Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He used natural rock set in concrete blocks for the wall. Many similar walls were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had design problems. These walls were only vertical, unlike natural cliffs with overhangs and angled rocks. Once built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers got bored with the same holds. In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a material that could be shaped like natural rock. These shapes could be attached to any wall and changed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started using panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls, but steel frames could be set up anywhere. This system allowed climbers to have endless new holds to try.'

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it's 'risky' very quickly. And yes, acting is a risky career. There are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were your friends might say you're crazy, but others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But it's a personal choice, and only you can take responsibility for your decision and your dream. There are no easy ways to become an actor - no exams to pass, and no guarantee that after training, you will succeed. It's about luck and talent. However, there is a need for new faces and talent, and acting can be exciting, glamorous, and sometimes very rewarding. People often ask what talent is. I think it's natural skill plus imagination, which is hard to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you're doing. Why do people want to act? It's hard to explain why you want to act. In theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is central to all acting and motivates actors. If you ask actors how they succeeded, they might just shrug. They know some things about themselves and their techniques, but they don't take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs. Suddenly, you get an audition, but even if you want the job, you might not get it. So, actors don't talk much about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of competing for roles and the possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, from the moment you start auditioning, you are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. It's up to you because if you don't care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone: Our Top Cookbook Picks**

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and are known for being exciting yet practical for the average cook. Her book, "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course," is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple, expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes. The book has been updated recently and is perfect for anyone who wants just one essential cookbook.

B. Raymond Blanc became a top chef and owner of a famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His book, "Blanc Mange," accompanies his first TV series. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by explaining how ingredients work together. He believes cooking is easy when you understand what's happening in the pan. The book includes over 80 recipes and explains why some dishes might not turn out well, using basic food chemistry. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows how good he is at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is known for the best in classical French cooking. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, the school released "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," featuring 100 respected recipes. These classic recipes are still fresh and have been updated to be healthier. The book starts with kitchen basics and includes sections on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is shown with step-by-step illustrations and photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide share their famous recipes and secrets.

D. Fast food doesn't have to be bad food. Nigel Slater, food editor of The Observer, proves this with his book, "The 30-Minute Cook." He believes you can make something delicious in the time it takes to order a pizza. His book includes over 200 quick and tasty recipes from around the world, all ready in 30 minutes. Nigel's writing style is fun and enjoyable, and his recipes show that fast food can also be great food. If you doubt it, try his recipes—they're simply delicious.

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher joked, 'What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall at that age. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More and more tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We are now overcoming the effects of many years of poor diet, which is having a big impact. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals occasionally. This lifestyle is still followed by a few remaining tribes of hunter-gatherers. One study found that they ate 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, farming was invented, which had serious consequences. Most green areas on the planet have been taken over by farmers, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This poor diet has badly affected human health and body size. Over the centuries, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing of the New World, was actually a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists.
