However, farming spread because it could support ten times more people than hunting and gathering. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier countries. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now similar to our ancestors' rich diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it also brings challenges. Heights have increased, but the world hasn't changed much. Standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers have to constantly update their products. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot keep growing forever. There must be a natural limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, from the University, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller as an adaptation to the cold. (Large, round bodies are better at keeping in heat.) Since the climate has warmed, we have become slightly thinner and smaller, even with proper nutrition. As the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even more. In other words, global warming could counteract the growth of human beings.'

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became less exciting and more of a routine. He didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but he was suddenly made redundant. Although he didn't get a big payout, it was enough to start his farm. His big break came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, his reputation grew, and now he also sells meat by mail order. He is happy not to be in an office anymore, but he still works 80 to 90 hours a week and sells a product.

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. A career counsellor helped him, and he was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work for money. Ron and his family moved to the north of England, leaving their friends behind, but their friendships have survived, and many friends visit them.

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison was a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot, but the hours were long. She didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she never has. Her secret is having deadlines because her business is related to fashion, with collections and seasons. She feels happier and less stressed now, although she misses socializing with colleagues. She loves being responsible for her product, and if something goes wrong, she takes the blame.

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. He liked the excitement but didn't find the work rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. To change careers, he got qualifications in massage and then got part-time work at the Life Centre. He has no regrets and now feels in control of his life.

Title: A Childhood Game Turns Into a Business Success

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are turning a childhood game into a successful business. In their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, they often play an old game called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought the game from Quebec, Canada, to the USA. The family played it often, especially on weekends and holidays, and had a lot of fun.

When the family moved to New Mexico, they continued playing pichenotte. The game was unknown in the southern USA, so visitors were curious about it. Three years ago, Dave noticed their old pichenotte board was worn out, so he made a new one. It was so well-made that family and friends wanted their own boards.

To see if others were interested, the brothers took a board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people were skeptical, but once they tried it, they loved it. Dave researched the game's history and found it likely originated in India as a game called 'carroms.' It evolved into 'squails' in Britain and then became pichenotte in Quebec.

Pichenotte is a skill-based game for two to four players. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks,' which they flick across a board to score points. The game is quick, usually lasting about two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity, the brothers started making more boards and selling them at markets and craft fairs. The game became so popular that championships were organized, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. The brothers decided to make pichenotte boards full-time, setting up a workshop in their garage. They have made over 450 boards, each crafted from birchwood and mahogany, weighing 12kg and costing $595.

Although there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, the brothers are optimistic. They hope their business will grow enough to replace their garage workshop with a luxury car. Until then, they enjoy playing the game that might make them successful.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that a few years ago, this was just a piece of unused land, flat and covered with wild plants. For a long time, people thought it was worthless. But with careful planning and hard work, one man, with the constant support of his wife, transformed it into the beautiful place you see today. 

During the construction, many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you see now. Machines like bulldozers helped, but a lot of hard work was also needed. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted, chosen carefully to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was the idea of Colin Sims. He made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting when the village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastics to handle all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself. 

You'll notice that all models are made to the same scale, with great attention to detail. This was achieved through patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is a popular attraction, known for its high-quality work and upkeep. The techniques used here have been applied in other model villages in England and are even taught in some college courses.

All the model buildings show traditional British architecture and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower, inspired by manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around, you'll also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; a small mistake can mean hours of repair work. You can take photos from the paths, and dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. 

To make your visit more enjoyable, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press them to see the models in action. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. Let us know if any models did not meet the village's high standards, as we are always updating and improving them.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about us!

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the editors' code of practice. Although pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not common. Usually, these pictures cause a lot of harm to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization set up to handle such issues. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. Do intimate photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where privacy is expected, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't take action. It's shocking that the PCC didn't investigate on its own. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star didn't make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other unfair attacks? 

At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by their competitors and on TV and radio. The public wouldn't support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it wouldn't be profitable to hide and take pictures of celebrities. If the PCC decided to act like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC monitor all British press: national, regional, and magazines? There's also the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story they want to keep secret, which could come out if they complain. In this way, even the PCC might seem like an enemy.

A British comedian also suffered from the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor recently, when his family was photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', saying it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It's hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many people give advice to college graduates looking for their first job. This article, however, focuses on moving to a second job. We are not talking about those who are looking for another temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those who leave a job they don't like within the first few weeks. Instead, we are discussing those who are taking a real step in their career, choosing a job that matches their goals now that they have some experience, skills, and an idea of where they want to go. 

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to ask yourself if you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to higher levels of responsibility, or switch to a different field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop, and take on more responsibility.

If you feel like traveling, now is a good time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because the people were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her word processing skills. However, there was no chance to advance, so she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. In two and a half years, she has become more capable, and her job has grown. Her boss wanted to help her develop from the start. Her job title is the same, but her duties have changed. She has moved from mainly typing and phone work to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. She also deals with various questions, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves her in all her work and gives her specific projects and events to organize.

Title: What's the Secret to Being Confident?

Confident people might seem like they were always that way, but most of them have learned to be confident over time. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

A. Jenny
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At 25, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school changed my life and helped everything else fall into place.

B. Michaela
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive because I thought that's how confident people acted. But I learned that confidence means believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don't feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to overcome those fears.

C. Lisa
People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. In TV, looking confident is important. Interviewing people taught me that everyone gets nervous in important situations, and we feel better when talking to someone friendly. My mom once told me, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves.' That advice helped me. You gain confidence by facing things that scare you. I was nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I wouldn't be that scared again.

D. Barbara
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I've built it over the years. By doing my job and learning from mistakes, I become more confident. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You have to like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses that boost my self-esteem. They also encourage setting achievable goals. It's better to achieve small goals than aim too high and get nothing.

E. Kim
After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak up in meetings. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my opinions. When I started in politics, I was nervous about speaking in public. I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' Writing down notes helped me feel more secure. Everyone gets nervous about public speaking. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his broken kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them under the shade of the whispering trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, Malaysia, and watched the country's biggest and most serious kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held up the kites, and a line of nervous competitors held their kite strings, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites shot up into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability in the air, and how well they fly. 'Flying kites isn't too hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how it's done.' I had received five such invitations that day, and I decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, shiny room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't fit it into my plans. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving my car towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains covered with lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road suddenly ended at a river. A long, narrow boat was there to take people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' Before starting, it would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the path, I found a man waiting with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. The night was completely dark, filled with different sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and thousands of living creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was an amazing view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning hit the treetops. Seconds later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the huge raindrops. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the path. No one stays a stranger for long here. Back in Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were only being friendly. Kelantan might be best known for its kites, but I remember it more for its human kindness.'

**What kind of shopper are you?**

We all go shopping, whether we like it or not. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ...

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I'm a shopping addict - I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it makes me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband how much I've spent. I always say I spent less than I did because the real price sounds shocking.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I do, I know what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring, and there's always something I'd rather be doing.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and get in and out quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes gets it wrong!

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and disorganized, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish quickly!

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out to look around the shops with my friends, and we often end up spending money. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I'm a careful shopper - I like going, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go crazy. Sometimes I shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much!

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on a Saturday because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have a good idea of what I want, and I never buy things immediately. I look in other shops to find a better bargain - it takes me ages!

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I'm an unwilling shopper. Maybe because I work in the city center, the shops have lost their appeal for me. When I have to shop, I drag myself out, but I don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than put in a lot of effort shopping!

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE Like any other university, the Open University can give you a degree. However, you don't have to quit your job to study. It can also introduce you to many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the new experience of learning more. You will meet many different people. You might also find that your degree opens up new job opportunities. You don't actually go to the Open University for lectures; instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer software. You can attend one class a month if you want at an Open University center. Of course, there are exams to take, just like at any university. If you want to know more, simply fill out the form below. It could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will look at 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist waited for different flowers to bloom in their seasons. Miss Violet Churchman donated it in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
There are lectures every Wednesday to go with the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will speak about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery restaurant now has better and more services. With new kitchens, it offers a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery happen every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm, except Sundays. These tours show some of the Gallery's greatest pictures and the collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skills to cook for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. You need to pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organisation that provides outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. If you are visiting with a group, please let the centre know before you come.

Windsurfing - One-day course
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. Course fee: £32.50 (includes all equipment).

One-day adventure course
This is a great chance to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is designed to introduce adults to outdoor activities in a fun and relaxed way. You do not need to be very fit or have done these activities before. You just need to be interested. Course fee: £22.50.

Play Park
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group day and residential courses
We offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. We have three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of 12 to 36 people.

Summer adventure holidays (for ages 8-14)
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We make sure that all children only do activities that are right for their age and abilities. For this programme, children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health.

Stamp Collecting - A Hobby That Keeps Growing

Millions of people, young and old, enjoy stamp collecting because it is interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections and find a hobby that can last a lifetime. Starting a collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can get stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends around the world.

If you become serious about collecting, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways: we can send you a complete set on an envelope addressed to you, in a colorful information pack with interesting facts, or as individual stamps for you to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too. A two-year membership costs just £5, and there is a discount if a group joins together. This is great value for money. When you join, you get a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This pack includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also receive a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to add to your collection and addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you will receive the club magazine. It is full of competitions and quizzes and gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members around the world. Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You will enjoy looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection and searching for rare ones.

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun of stamp collecting. To join, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of receiving your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, the farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges, including Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here is some advice to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most people who wrote for us did this. Love, family, and problems with friends were the main topics. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Make the reader want to keep reading by writing about ordinary things in a new and surprising way. Get your facts right Don't describe a town or explain how something works if you are not sure about it. Only write about things you know well. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A bad ending is the worst. Develop the story carefully and try to think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters Make the people in your story come alive for the reader by using good words to make them seem real. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. Even if you are close to missing the deadline, we cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, your story cannot be returned, and we cannot discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or recorded form, like on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. Your £5 fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month of this date. Please note that if you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that his daughter received the best education possible. This was unusual because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. Although we do not have copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to help with her work. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone connected with it was in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in the east at Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is next to the main road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line. Ticket prices are £10.00 for adults, £5.00 for children, and £25.00 for a family (up to 2 adults and 3 children). Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from all over Europe. This includes famous trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can also see '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower', which were built in Britain. These engines are on display all year, even when the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only on days when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. For example, the James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or back in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train called 'Teddy Bear' with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a popular place for family events or company visits. It can provide an interesting afternoon or evening out. Special programs can include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, and more. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different types of grass, and they can be found everywhere on Earth. Grass is the only flowering plant that can live in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way. Grass can grow back quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new grass leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This allows large groups of animals to live in one area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow, providing fresh food.

Kal Kaur Rai, who has always loved fashion, recently won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to attend industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked, so she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. She then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes sold well, and nothing was returned. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand. Kal's parents were supportive of her career change, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels very fortunate and says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

SUNNINGDALE HOTEL

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has offered great service to people from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here. The hotel is located on a main road leading to the town center, about 20 minutes by bus. Buses to many parts of the town stop outside the hotel, but avoid buses with the blue "Express" sign as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished single rooms with central heating. Each room has hot and cold water basins, and showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the corridors. The hotel includes a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. Parking is available in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and stamps can be bought at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. During the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by signing the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires are allowed, and guests should respect others' comfort. Keep noise from tapes or CDs low, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If arriving by train, it is advised to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

Text: 'Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. However, his life wasn't always easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved acting in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with his thousands of fans worldwide.'

Title: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN?'

When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she ended up on a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and the cat were hungry. He gave her some milk and started asking around. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. Since it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he brought her to an animal hospital.

Meanwhile, Bo's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered something to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.

The Ghan Train

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin in northern Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm north coast through endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally built to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. A transcontinental railway is rare, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. As I waited to board the Ghan, everyone seemed excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners eager to board. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan waited four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip up the gorge. I left the train at Alice Springs for a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train might not have delivered everything the advertisements promised, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

Each year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is so far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time climbing Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We planned to climb the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is 600 meters high and is probably the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard that it feels like ice. Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, like lights to get attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon got steep, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb in the future. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we were not so lucky because a mist came down. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as hard as climbing up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I only really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we moved into our new school building! It's an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. But this new school is special because it's one of the first in our country to be very environmentally friendly. It took months to build, and we watched it happen. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, although it meant losing some nice open space. The noise from the machines was very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think it would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are much bigger than the ones in our old school next door. We also have a room that people from the town can use for meetings. There's a nursery, a lovely dining room, and big changing rooms that we can't wait to use when our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you'll notice there are no heaters! The heat comes from us - the children, teachers, and computers. The building is designed to keep all the heat inside, and it keeps the sound in too. So, when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is the tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it's a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for our lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins really fast. It's so big that you can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on our website.

Even though we're using the new school, some parts are still being added. For example, we're putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready next year. We're very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we'll learn much faster here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**

Simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**

As a special offer, you can choose any discounted books from our new members' book list, up to a total value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you will save money compared to the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully chosen by our staff from our book list. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you've joined:**

As a member, you'll save between 30% and 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month, which will keep you updated with the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:**

While you are a member, we ask you to choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want to buy. In each monthly club magazine, our experienced staff select a Club Choice book—a fiction or reference book they think is worth buying—offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just indicate this on the form. We will send the book if we do not receive your response.

So, return your application form today, but hurry—offers like this are rare. To apply, simply fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Soon, your books will be with you. Please don't send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never thought that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground and actually enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us spent the morning caving, while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but felt happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what happened, it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I explained my situation. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had my handbag and offered to drive over to return it. I got my handbag back, with everything inside untouched. I want to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Sharks are some of the most scary animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes them very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if you turn a shark over on its back, it can stop moving completely. This is helpful for scientists who study sharks because it lets them learn more about these interesting animals.

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only £1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Scheduled flights with Qantas, Australia's national airline, from London or Manchester to Perth, and returning from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, you will take Air Australia flights between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. There is a coach from Sydney to Melbourne, passing through Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia are included. You will stay for nineteen nights in good hotels with a full continental breakfast each day. The trip includes a day visit to Ayers Rock, a full-day boat trip on the Barrier Reef, a visit to an Australian sheep station, and city sightseeing tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All state and local taxes are covered. Hotel baggage handling is included. An experienced Globewise Tour Manager will be with you throughout the trip. PERTH Enjoy long, golden beaches, excellent restaurants with great food, lush green parks, and the beautiful Swan River. A city sightseeing tour is included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to Alice Springs, located in the heart of Aboriginal country. A full sightseeing tour is included. Visit the Flying Doctor base and 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Travel to Yulara National Park. Visit the mysterious Olgas and Ayers Rock, known for its caves and Aboriginal rock paintings. Then fly to the lively seaside town of Cairns and relax in the sun. GREAT BARRIER REEF A full day's boat trip on the famous reef is included, with the chance to see amazing, brightly colored fish and other sea creatures. SYDNEY Experience the excitement and beauty of Australia's biggest city. A sightseeing tour and a visit to the famous Opera House are included. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE A city sightseeing tour is included, or you can visit the Penguin Parade. We promise that by the end of the trip, you'll want to return!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov's ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around me, asking questions in Russian. I tried to speak some Russian, and then they started talking in English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is really nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once to talk to her because I felt a little lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are really hard, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. That makes me confident I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I like walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when I couldn't believe how cold it was. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. Right now, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

The ICEHOTEL

For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. In winter, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, people started to see the dark and cold winter as something special. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit opened an art exhibition in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, some foreign guests decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it is famous worldwide.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the completion date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Warm winter clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and plenty of wool socks. It's a good idea to wear shoes that are larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store. There were many special deals, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The store's regular hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had said it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening. A police officer who was called to the store said: 'The police knew a big crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store quickly filled up, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly until there was room for them inside. Another problem was the long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. What surprised me was that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the store. This caused the road to be completely blocked.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the store, said: 'I waited in line for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. So I'll come back when they reopen, but I'm not willing to wait in line again.'

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of Britain's most active arts groups.

**Society Magazines**  
We create several great magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by top British writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and lots of information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing world. You can read some articles from recent issues by following the links on this website.

**National Short Story Competition**  
We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and you can write about any topic. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society do not pay an entry fee, but non-members pay £5. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will get a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

**Education**  
For almost thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms to give children and teachers new ideas and help them feel more confident in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, for writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and can attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**  
The Writers' Cafe is the social hub of the Society. It is relaxed and stylish, offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**  
We have members all over the world, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Tanya Streeter is a famous free-diver with four world records. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath. In 2003, Tanya became the first person to dive 120 meters deep and return without help, holding her breath for over three and a half minutes. This achievement made her the only woman to break a man's world record in any sport. A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of past accidents, but Tanya believes safety and training are most important.

Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine stays the same. She spends two-thirds of her time training on land at the gym and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, preferring fast walking instead. When practicing dives, she usually travels and aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, resting between each dive to avoid getting tired.

When not training, Tanya often appears in public to promote sports products and supports environmental causes by doing research or making films. Growing up on Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, she loved swimming and exploring sea life, and she feels her current life is like living her childhood dreams. Tanya is well-known in some countries, which helps her talk about environmental issues. In her thirties now, she plans to keep breaking her own records and doesn't intend to stop free-diving anytime soon, as she only started at age twenty-five.

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, people in the cinema world thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors had some new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was a success. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Title: New TV Star Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role

Caroline Benson, a new TV star, shares her experience about her first TV role. She says, "I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before starting university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. Filming started a week after university began, so I got permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on my essays. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I'm so lucky. After university, I definitely want to pursue acting as a career. I'm not from an acting family, although my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I didn't know what to do. I've since acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends."

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to make enough money to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a global company that is growing quickly around the world. Over the years, I have learned a lot. Many of these lessons are in this book because I believe our company has important ideas about running a successful business while staying true to our values. This is not a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The main idea is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can have a positive impact. In business, as in life, I need to have fun, feel like part of a family, and be excited by new challenges. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with the world. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that thought exciting, and I hope you do too.'

Text: 'A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER

JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can host 160 guests in double cabins, each with a private shower and toilet. The ship has air-conditioning and features a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

Itinerary

Day 1: Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the early evening. A guide will meet you upon arrival and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

Day 2: Enjoy a morning tour of Oporto, then return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the river journey takes four hours.

Day 3: Continue traveling up the river. In the early evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua, known for port wine. You can enjoy local food and drinks at dinner.

Day 4: After breakfast, take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego to visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum. The museum, once a palace, has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.

Day 5: The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return to Tua is by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

Day 6: In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take a scenic train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

Day 7: Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, travel down the river back to Oporto, where you will sleep on board.

Day 8: Arrive in Oporto with time for independent sightseeing and last-minute shopping before flying back to London Heathrow.'

HONEY

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who even used it as money. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that it can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. But honey is not just food - it can also be used for sore throats and is an ingredient in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of England's largest towns. Norwich is known for its religious diversity, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second-largest city in England. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as weeks in the year and as many pubs as days in the year. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and success as a commercial center, especially in insurance services, Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options: theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries,' with green and yellow colors, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's attractions is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall.' For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the city center as builders worked on the project. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a city center park on the roof of the Mall, with water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas are successful, showing that Norwich has combined the best of the old and the new.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. Back then, there were about twelve hot-air balloons that took off from a parking lot in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at the current location outside the city.

What to See

The balloon pilots stay in contact with each other by radio and light up their balloons' burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to take off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, and some are shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will really enjoy it.

In the afternoon, you can take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere and offers a great view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

Practical Advice

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long lines at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you are not using a digital camera, you will need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

The Eden Project

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular places to visit. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is amazing to see how many products we use every day come from plants, like wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a big waterfall. Another zone copies the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to build a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Having 500 pages of original writing of this quality for just £6.99 is quite impressive. Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less well-known writers seem to focus mainly on food. Be careful with Jane Harris's Those Nails - it's best not to read it right after eating because it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset your stomach! The book also features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are also parts of novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers and an extraordinary piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is an exceptional collection, and I am excited to see what next year's selection will include.'

The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to start teaching children at three or four years old, but she sometimes makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, once every two weeks. In addition, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents also need to attend the classes. It is important that parents show interest in the lessons. From the beginning, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and reading of music. Margaret says her method is not meant to create great violinists, and she often suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Moonshine, the band, released their third CD last week. The new album, 'Here Again', follows their previous one, 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year. Also, Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance tune, it's clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans, but they could easily become hit singles because they are excellent. Singer Rob Letchford shows his talent by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems, which caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets should not worry because all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was discovered from the land, not from the sea. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. But it wasn't the gold seekers who became rich. The wealthiest people made money by owning banks and law firms, and they built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of the time, like disease, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, even about his faults - he often slept during church or looked at the pretty girls. He describes his home life - a quarrel with his wife and how they became friends again, and his worry about her illness. Besides books, he liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and lots of fun. Pepys was a busy man who had many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work for the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not made to be comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins that people wrapped around their ankles in cold weather. Today, we still use leather, but we also use materials like silk, plastic, or cotton, depending on what is fashionable. About one hundred and fifty years ago, people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could fit either the left or right foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, even though some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry make many more shoes at a lower cost for more people.'
